Fixed flletwood a/c control
irv2 and its contributors have been a valuable resource for people like me who own an older motor-home. In particular, I want to do a special thank you to Waiter21. Its people like him that make irv2 the valuable resource it's become.
I'm getting ready for a trip in a few weeks, but having problems with my A/C and furnace, They come on and run for no reason, and are totally unreliable. It got to the point where I was turning the circuit breakers on/off to run the units manually. I need to get this fixed before my trip
Searching through posts on irv2, this seemed to be a common problem with older Intellitec ECC control systems. Waiter21 chimed in and offered several things to get the system working, cleaning the switches and sliders, look carefully at the circuit boards for corrosion and bad solder joints especially where the connectors plugs are. He gave me his phone number and we talked on the phone. Everything looked ok, but when I tested it, there wasn't any change He suggested calling Intellitec, they may be able to repair my boards, and also check with Fleetwood, they may have some new boards in stock.
He then said he had one other option that I might be interested in. He does electronics and computers as a hobby, and had been working on a replacement for his Intellitec system. He had so much documantion that he put together a dedicated web site just for this (he does web sites as a hobby also). I wasn't expecting a lot but went there as a last resort just to see what he had done.
www.waiterecc.com
WOW - This is AWSOME
After talking to Intellitec and Fleetwood, I called Waiter21 about what it would take to get one of his systems. (his real name is John) He said he doesn't offer these for sale because he's still tweaking on it, and the market is so small its probably not a viable commercial product. He said he'd let me have one at cost, but I needed to review all the installation, operation, and technical stuff on the web site, install and operate it, then report back any problems or suggestions for improvement. He called it BETA testing.
He sent me a system, circuit board, operator panel, temperature sensor, and some custom wire bundles. It took about 2 hours to install everything. When I turned it on, IT WORKED.. I followed his recommendation to do a calibration of the original temperature sensors, they were within 1 degree.
As I operated the system over the next few days, I had two questions for him. The AUTO COOL seemed to operate a little differently than the original Intellitec. (I like the new way). He said several others had suggested changeing how the blower operates in AUTO. Everyone likes the new process, when A/C reches the set point, blower turns off about 30 seconds after the compressor turns off.
The other big one for me was the temperature display. I live in Canada and we do things the correct way, in Celsius. When I called him, he said â€œDARN, I never even thought of thatâ€. That afternoon, he calls me back and says to check my email. He had made a change to the software so you can configure it to either display in F or C. He then walked me through how to upload this change to my system.
This whole experience has been absolute awesome, If it hadn't been for irv2 and Waiter21, I probably would have spent a thousand dollars to fix the old system. Instead, I now have a modern system that has all kinds of neat features, at a small fraction of the cost. Again, Thank you Waiter21, you have some really neat hobbies.
If you're having problems with your Intellitec system, and it looks like its not repairable, take a look at what Waiter21 has put together. Visit his web site and check out his system. Contact him and see what it would take to get one of these for you motor-home. www.waiterecc.com

Well gang,
I noticed a few drops of pink type fluid on my RV garage floor so I got under it to check out just what it was. It could have been tranny fluid or coolant. It was coolant. A loose radiator hose
clamp for a radiator lower hose was that culprit. But, while under there I noticed the water pump belt was quite loose on our CAT C-7 330HP. Well it was a major operation to do what was needed to be done. I had to yank the radiator, air intake
tube, and slide out the basement A/C 3/4 of the way.
All of that was needed to gain access to the fastening bolts/screws etc. that retain the radiator and CAC in our '04 Itasca Horizon 36GD. I had to yank the radiator simply because, I could not get to ONE BOLT that is used to secure the water pump belt tensioner so I could tighten the water pump belt. When I finally got to it, I found the tensioner was very rough in rotation so, I removed it and installed new bearings. While in there, I installed new bearings in both my serpentine belt tensioner and the serpentine belt idler.
And, might as well install some new belts while in there too. Once that was all back together, I dove into removing the S-cam rollers on my front brakes and clean and lube all that stuff up. I re-adjusted the slack adjusters, took it all out for a test drive and, no leaks in the rear of the coach, no clunk in the brake application and, all is well. Man these things are a pain in the A...
But, hopefully, I'm good for quite a while and can use it with confidence that important stuff is taken care of.
Scott

We lost our satellite reception a year ago. Last June, our dealer replaced the receiver with a Wally and the dome antenna with a Playmaker. They could not get it to lock on to the satellite's. We needed the coach for a trip and we do not watch TV much on the road, so we let it go. They tried again in Sept before we left for the south, but still no cigar. After several attempts on my own, I finally have reception, but still confused. It turned out that both coax cables from the playmaker (Tiffin had a spare cable) would carry 13.25 volts to the antenna, but would not carry a signal back to the receiver. The HDMI powered splitter was also bad. I finally have a perfect picture with sound by running an external coax from antenna through the gap of a bedroom slide into the receiver and using the powered HDMI splitter that was intended for Traveler Sat antenna which we do not have. I am at a a loss as to how or why both OEM coax cables and the HDMI splitter could be bad. I tried eliminating different combinations of each component, but could not single out just one of them. Now, the simplest permanent solution is to run the new coax down next to the middle AC unit
into the ceiling and down the wall. Maybe I'll never know the cause.

Well, yesterday when attempting to replace my air pressure spin on filter, it wouldn't budge using my strap wrench. Then for trying to slip my metal big over the cannister, it's jammed tight against the air hoses. Sooooooo, now for removing and putting spacers behind the bolts, which entailed doing the same for a little piece next to it, connected by a plastic hose that's barely long enough. All it takes is a little slack on this stuff instead of stretching everything so tight. Not blaming it on engineers with bean counters following them around, however.
Anyway, my filter wrench
easily slipped over it now and for easily coming loose.
By the way and for those doing so, don't forget to bleed all the air out or you might not ever break it free. Mine has an air valve on the line next to it, but you may have to bleed the tanks with the lanyards' or for crawling down under to do so.

Sounds like I am not the only one with cable issues. We have not been able to get cable to work at any RV parks, but have only been to about 7 or so since we bought our '21 Cornerstone. Since the dealer, MHSRV in Texas, said they couldn't do it for a couple of weeks when we BOUGHT the coach, we figured we would wait and take care of it later. Well, later has arrived. I contacted DISH and DTV, and since we don't have either one at our home, the quote is $177 a month for MOST of the channels we actually want. Hmmm, for part timers, not sure that sounds quite right. Then I meet a nice couple in Naples that said they plug in a device like an Apple TV box, and they are tied to their home account and it doesn't cost them anything. ?? I call Apple, as we have multiple Apple boxes at home, and they said they don't know anything about RV's. I call the closest Entegra dealer, and they say to order the receiver and set up the plan we want, then bring it to them and they will sort it out for me. I just can't quite seem to get my arms around the simple facts. I have a Winegard satellite on the roof already, so it should be simple, but beyond my expertise. And no one I have talked with knows how to get in motion satellite/wi-fi, so I am hoping the dealer can do it.
The only thing I fixed my myself lately is my drawer under the entry steps that would keep popping open on all my LH turns. Dealer said they fixed it, but on the first corner leaving the dealership, the drawer slammed into the entry door again. So when I got home, I figured out how to remove the drawer, then discovered there was a screw missing inside that held the back of the drawer in position with a magnet holding the drawer shut. After shimming up with an additional magnet, the problem was solved.
Now, if I can just learn all the tech-y stuff

Departing Gulf Shores, Alabama, last week I heard a flapping noise under the engine cover. I removed the cover and found the engine serpentine belt was disintegrating . The spare belt was folded tightly and didn't want to spread out to fit the many pulleys so after several unsuccessful attempts I ended up using tape to hold it on the alternator and A/C compressor pulleys while I crawled underneath to connect everything else. The Chevy 8.1 engine has the belt tensioner underneath, and a 3/8 breaker bar
is used to rotate it to release the belt tension. It's very handy to have a small ratchet strap to hold the breaker bar
in position while attaching the serpentine belt. Also, a pair of needle nose pliers
to remove remains of the belt that had wrapped around the fan hub. The good news is that I caught this in time to pull into a shopping center for replacement rather than having a complete failure on the interstate highway

The HDMI splitter failure is a known problem with Tiffin coaches. They overheat due to their mounting location. Several people have said they mounted a cooling fan
near the splitter to keep it cool. Search for this problem on this site to find the solution.

I had same problem. Discovered I was not waiting long enough for the sat dish to lock on to the sat signal. It takes about 10 minutes to lock to sat signal. Also had to inspect and exercise the dip switches on the in motion receiver circuit card inside the dome sat antenna.

As I am getting ready for our weekend trip I look at my load control panel and it has an odd message. It has the model, software version, and a message "no communication" on it. So I find the mfg, Precision Circuits on the web and give them a call. The fellow answers the phone and I tell him my problem. He says it sound like the data cable may have popped off. So I pull the panel by my breaker box and check. The data cable looks like a phone cord and I see it going into the box. It's hard to get to and I try reseating it. No change. Then I pull the monitor panel out in the front of the coach. I unplug the cable and plug it back in. Bingo! Back to working again. I think I might have accidentally unseated the cable at the breaker box a couple of weeks ago when I was pulling a coax cable. Everything worked for the rest of my trip, so I think it's fixed.

Well,
For those of you that may need replacement mud flaps
, the ones behind the duals, not the long-full length one, I just did it today. For the life of me, I could not find them in the Winne parts catalog. So, I called a few auto parts
stores in my area. Napa was the winner here. They had several different flaps I could choose from.
I ended up choosing the cheapest ones they had. They are good quality rubber and are, 24" x 24" and don't have any logo or name on them. They are about 1/4" thick with some ribbing here and there for structural strength.
But, my flaps ( maybe as well as many of yours out there in RV land) are only 23.5" wide by 12" long. So, I could have purchased one single flap and cut two out of it. But, based on the design of them, I would have ended up with one that had rounded corners at the bottom and one with square corners, not good.
So, for a measly $26 for the two of them total, I got two. I cut the bottom half to be used for the flaps. The reason I used the bottom half is because the corners were already rounded. I had gasket hole punches from Harbor Freight already so, punching those holes in that rubber, was a piece of cake.
It's all done and, they look great. So, if anyone has some sad looking mud flaps
or, they're completely gone or aged, check your local Napa store.

Our Atwood electric/propane hot water heater would not heat water using electric mode. I read that the element had probably went bad so this weekend I changed it out. This was not a difficult job if you pull the hot water tank out completely. The element was caked in calcium and rust but what was disturbing the electrical wiring connected to the element had gotten so hot that it had melted one of the wire nuts breaking the connection . So I replace the element and the relay and cleaned up all of the wiring and I now have hot water using the electric mode. My question if anyone knows, 'would the calcium buildup cause a short causing the wiring to basically fry?'.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Harricat55
Our Atwood electric/propane hot water heater would not heat water using electric mode. I read that the element had probably went bad so this weekend I changed it out. This was not a difficult job if you pull the hot water tank out completely. The element was caked in calcium and rust but what was disturbing the electrical wiring connected to the element had gotten so hot that it had melted one of the wire nuts breaking the connection . So I replace the element and the relay and cleaned up all of the wiring and I now have hot water using the electric mode. My question if anyone knows, 'would the calcium buildup cause a short causing the wiring to basically fry?'.
My water heater was completely loaded with calcium buildup but the wiring was unaffected so I'm not sure if that could cause the wires to get hot. I also spent several hours cleaning out the deposits which were caked to the tank lining below the heating element. You probably had/have the same condition if it built up enough to cover the heating element. I had to spend several hours chiseling away the deposits with a long screwdriver by removing both the heating element and the anode rod for access. Works great now though.

Just moved my Progressive Dynamics EMS-PT50C Surge Protector (portable unit) inside the power cord bay. Disconnected the power cord from the automatic transfer switch and ran it to a female 50 amp connector mounted on the back wall of the power cord bay. Installed a short (30 inch) 50 amp male end power cord to the transfer switch. Now I can plug the EMS-PT50C into the female plug on the back wall and plug the short male end from the transfer switch in to the EMS-PT50C. Now the surge protector stays in the power bay and is out of sight and out of the weather and always plugged in. Easy to remove if I ever sell the MH or have to send back to the factory for repairs.

Well,
If I were to display all I've done on our coach, an '04 Itasca Horizon 36GD with the C-7 330HP CAT, either lately, or, since the day we purchased it, I'd take up another 15 or 20 pages. We love this coach and all about it. But, it is truly amazing on what I have had to do, in terms of repair on it. I have a spread sheet created by Excell and, even I'm amazed at what I've done. The most recent repair was installing a new water tank/city water diversion valve in the water compartment.
And that caused me to have to drain the water tank so I wouldn't keep getting rained on while in there for repairs. Well, when I went to fill the tank, drip, drip, drip, etc. at a fairly rapid pace, from the bottom of the coach. CRAP, now what? Well, it turned out to be the water tank drain valve. Since it had never been used, when I used it to drain the water, it apparently developed a bad seal. So, I had to dive into that one. $12.00 later and, about 2 hours labor, all done, new valve.
Scott

bay storage door wouldnâ€™t unlock both sides, preventing the door from opening. eventually got a thin, flat screwdriver in and tapped the latch bolt open. once open i could see the latch bolt wasnâ€™t retracting fully.
the interior of the door / locking mechanism was covered by a sheet of plastic riveted by a *ton* of rivets. multi-tooled a large opening, tightened and star-washered the linkage and itâ€™s back to 100%.

So this might be a mute point this time of the year for most. However it is still fairly warm here in AZ. As most have mentioned, the AC on most MH's are inept at best. Those that have 2 units not so much. Saying that, I wanted to see why ours was having trouble even in 90'F weather. It seems that the channels are the full length of the coach. Meaning that the channels run past the registers. I went through and plugged the channels that went past any register with foam. It made a huge improvement in delivering the cold air into the room. I have included a pic. 2 channels that extended past the register about 2 to 3 feet.

Just replaced sprayer hoses and connections on 1999 Newmar Dutchstar. Drilled out hose connections on wiper base with 1/8 drill and replaced them with 1/8 brass pipe frim Ace hardware. Two weeks ago we drove from SW Michigan to Gulf Shores Alabama. The cruise started acting up right away. Would kick off when we hit a bump. Wouldn't come back on for some time and then would start to work. Finally quit entirely about halfway. We had a 1999 Windstar that did the same thing. It was the brake fluid pressure switch so I thought it might be the same thing. Got to Gulf Shores and did a bunch of research. Found the part number. Had to order it from a local Ford dealer as no one else had it. $42 and a day later had it in my hand. R&R'd it at the campground. Fast forward to today, we drove to La Belle Florida (10.5 hour drive) from Gulf Shores and the cruise worked perfectly. Yeah!! Love it!

Quote:

I used 2000 grit wet/dry sandpaper. Kept the plastic surface wet, noticed a 75%-95% improvement after 5 minutes or so. You may want to put painters tape around the adjoining painted edges.
If the lenses are nasty, start with 600 wet/dry on a sponge, work up through 1000, 1500 and finally 2000 grit; always using plenty of water. Taping adjoining surfaces is smart.
After the 2000, either hand or electric polisher with rubbing compound, followed by car wax.
If you're willing to spend an hour apiece on the headlights, they will turn out clear as new.

Don't know if you got it fixed but the problem is likely to be melted actuators. They are car door lock actuators
. They have a plastic case. If the relay that supplies 12vdc sticks, 12vdc is applied continuously. This causes the actuator
to overheat and the housing melts .... then the actuator is stuck. Typically multiple actuators will get stuck at the same time. Try every door ... you may find 1 you can unlock with the key. This is NOT a good problem to have. If you can get 1 hatch open you may be able to get into the other bays by crawling thru. Fixing the problem depends on the RV make/model/yr..

Quote:
Originally Posted by Forkyfork
One thing I don't know a lot about the fords but the Chevys are sensitive to having a dirty MAF sensor
, have they checked all the sensors?
The Ford's is easily cleanable with special MAF cleaner (don't use carb cleaner).
So, it's worth doing just to do. You need "special" security Torx bit (the one with the pin in the middle of the "star") to remove the MAF.
Do it while inspecting / replacing the air cleaner.
The Fords (depending on year) have issues with water ingestion into the air filter that also temporarily screws up MAF (just clean it, new filter dry the box to fix).

I tell him to push it back out in the parking lot and I will get it and do it myself. Geez
Now, to be fair to the tech - he could have been right.
DexCool is an OAT style coolant, and it doesn't mix well with others - including some of the newer OAT (purple) formulations. If it inadvertently gets mixed with the standard glycol coolants with silica aditives you will have a mess that resembles mud. It will form globules that tend to block smaller passages. DexCool is an OAT coolant. I would never mix one of the "Universal" coolants with it. Those that are advertised as "universal" do not meet all of the DexCool specifications. You can buy DexCool compliant coolants from Prestone and Zerex. Even Peak branded coolant, which really pushes their "universal" coolant offers a DexCool specific product. For those of us with HOAT coolants in our vehicles, it looks like the Zerex G05 is the only coolant meeting all of those specifications. Like before, you don't want to mix OAT and HOAT coolants. Anyone adding a universal coolant to an HOAT system will be introducing additive packages that will break down the original fill and cause problems.
I have worked on vehicles that have had issues from the wrong coolant being added. Gone are the days of just grabbing a jug of the green stuff and filling your vehicle radiator. Of course, also gone are the days of annual coolant flushes and refills.....
I am always very careful when it comes to adding coolant to a vehicle. I check the owner's manual to ensure that the proper type is used. The same goes for automatic transmission fluid
- the wrong type added can certainly ruin your day!

Well 1200 miles into a 1600 mile round trip I lost my camera then the engine started revving real high. Turned out the chassis battery was bad. I noticed low voltage when the engine started acting up.
Pulled over on the side of the road just east of elko Nevada, pulled the chassis battery and swapped it with a house battery.
Started right up and got is the rest of the way home.
That is probably the main reason I wont switch to series parallel 6 volt batteries. Would have been there hours I'm sure waiting for someone to help.
All in all I was back on the road in about 20 minutes

"That is probably the main reason I wont switch to series parallel 6 volt batteries. Would have been there hours"
My two 12 volt engine batteries and four 6 volt chassis batteries are in the same tray. If that would happen to me, worse case is to disconnect chassis, and move the engine battery leads to the + of the in series 6 volts and the - at the other end (to get 12volts). No way would I put 12 volt batteries in as chassis for longevity reasons.

Norcold 2 door fridge/freezer. The bottom of the refrigerator door was hanging up when opening, and we had to nudge the bottom of door with a knee when closing to get it to seat all the way in.
Finally went out to look at it today. So easy, I should of done this last year when it started. The door comes right off by unscrewing the top hinge pin. A few small washers on the bottom hinge for the door to ride on and done. Raised the door just enough to solve the problem. 5 minute fix.

Just completed 48K service plus coolant flush; purchased and installed new dually valve stem extenders and dropped PSI to that Michelin Tire Chart recommends after having 4 corner weighed. THEN I just had 45 minutes of fun scooting around under my new to me DP checking things out on my new creeper.

Replaced the 50amp hardwired shore cord. Plug to pedestal had cracks in it. Screwed on aftermarket plugs were dimensionally too big to fit in hole (port) on RV when retracted. So new cord with molded in plug was required. Old cord was in good condition, so I bought ends and made a 10' extension cord.

Polished cloudy headlamp lenses. They're sandblasted from 10 years and 90000 miles. Grabbed my random orbital buffer, used polishing compound and spent about 15 minutes buffing each. Cleaned off residue/dust and applied a coat of Rejex - they look new and I used stuff I already owned.

Added indicator light on my toad to verify that it's getting 12V from the Motorhome when the MH ignition is on. That 12 volts charges the Toad battery, plus it provides power to the electronic steering on my Jeep Cherokee which has a wiring mod. so that it can flat tow safely. Part of the mod required you to insert and remove a fust under the hood so that the steering would work to prevent death wobble. So, I used a relay to power the steering - rather than having to go under the hood to install a fust - and then remove it at the end of the day.

I had the anti freeze
flushed out and new anti freeze
added to the Cat engine.

Today, I tackled restringing a day/night shade (4 cord version with two springs) and the operation was a success. So, I just ordered more cord as I have a couple more to do. And, I installed some LED bulbs (50 watt equivalent) in the lighting fixtures in the living/dinette area.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0...?ie=UTF8&psc=1
The fixtures have room for two bulbs per fixture, but only one of these bulbs will fit in each fixture, so I think the overall brightness will be equivalent to 70 watts, and we really needed more light than the 40 watts equivalent per fixture that came in the motorhome when we bought it.

Tightened down the leaking input lines to the HW heater. I'm guessing they managed to work loose over the last 18 months as they just started to leak. Got a good 1/2 -> 3/4 turn on each and the leaks have stopped.

We replaced the awning fabric
today. About 3 hours and 3 people. Not to bad to do. This is the second time in 4 years we had to replace the fabric. The original lasted 13 years. The fabric we used to replace that only lasted 4 years. Never use Sun Wave fabric. This time we used Dometic replacement fabric.

fixed the slide room motor controller, adjust the other two on the passenger side.
I AM ready to get out of dodge.

Replaced fuel tank
sending unit, ordered from Alliance Coach as the mfg will not sell direct, $169.12. Total time including color coding wires, used colored zip ties, about 40 minutes. Easy job, had to enlist help from Son-in-law as my oversize belly would not allow me to safely get to the access cover in the storage compartment. Now for the first fill up. Was informed the unit comes preset from factory. Easy fix.

Woke up Sunday morning at 4am with the unmistakable smell of burning electrical. Scary! Apparently the electric element in my water heater shorted out and burned up the EMS control board(s).
Being repaired tomorrow with two new boards and a new electric element for water heater. A tad over $1,000 parts and labor. Ouch, but could have been much worse.

Just replaced my series-32 kwikee step motor the plastic gear in it was stripped. On our last trip the step hit the ground when extended and never worked the same again. All works fine now.

Moved my Remco 55 Aquajet-RVA water pump away from the wet bay wall, where it had been jammed at the Thor factory, nearly completely crimping off the inlet hose.
I saw this when taking out my Kantleak valve, which was dripping steady. The pump was also screwed to the wet bay flooring a wierd angle due to the indents in the floor. I used a short section of poly Board from Lowe's
I had left over, and rubber grommets to secure the board in s level configuration. I then mounted the pump to the flat board, bring sure to move it away from the wall enough to free up the inlet hose. Put it all back together, and wired in a switch to the 12v supply for the pump so I can turn the pump on, and off, when I'm working on the plumbing outside.
All worked out great, and I have increased water pressure!
My pump still will not cut off, after all valves are closed, it never has stopped completely.
I have checked for leaks, and found none.
Anyone have any idea what to look for next?

Maxjr758, check to see if your "city fill" valve is completely shutting off. If it is not closed off entirely, or if the valve is not seating properly, the pressure the pump builds up will slowly leak past the "city fill" valve, back into the fresh water tank, resulting in lowered pressure, and your pump starting up to maintain the proper pressure. This happens to me if I forget to completely close off the city fill valve. Hope this helps!

City water valve -tank fill valve.
We had that same problem. Got so bad that we'd only turn the pump on when needed. Finally took the valve apart and stuck in a new washer. What a difference a 50Â¢ part can make sometimes!

This happens to me if I forget to completely close off the city fill valve. Hope this helps!
I have the Anderson 'Kantleak" valve . I called Remco, they say completely fill the fresh water tank, open all faucets(hot and cold), run the washing machine, shower, outdoor shower, flush the toilets 3-4 times. This to get all the air out of the system, which they say I why the pump won't shut off. Said any air in the system is seen as a demand for water, by the sensor circuit In the pump controller.
I will check before I use all that water.

Water pump case seal failed and leaked. Some water damage to the OSB shelf the 50 gallon water tank is set on which is buried under the bed along the back wall of the coach.
Removed the bed and framing to gain access. With the tank out, all the associated plumbing and the problem pump I was able to dry out the wood out with heaters. Couple of soft spots but for the most part the shelf was sound. Sealed the OSB with penetrating epoxy, replaced the pump with a better model and rework the plumbing adding soft flexible tubing to help quiet the pump. Reworked the framing for the bed, side shelves along with insulating and draft sealing the entire area.
The epoxy worked out really well. Very thin and penetrated the OSB eliminating the soft spots and preventing further water damage should the tank or plumbing ever leak again.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0...?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The gasket in your pictures is the exhaust manifold
to turbo gasket. Intake side of exhaust housing if you like, but still the exhaust side. It's the exhaust pressure that spins the compressor wheel to build boost.
Your compressor wheel is the damaged one. Something got into the intake piping and did that damage. I have seen it many, many times when I worked on trucks.
Happy Glamping.

Got to camp and water was dripping out of one of my storage bays. Looked into it after tearing my bed apart to access the water tank and found the vent hose had come detached from the gravity fill port on the outside. Got it all dried out and hooked back up. Love it when it's an easy fix!!

2004 MADP: My weekend project was to make it easier for DW to use the coach's dash stereo. She gets up early and likes to listen to the radio while getting ready for the day. I found and ordered a Carling L24D1 DPDT (on-none-on) rocker switch that matches the coach's original dash rocker switches and fits exactly in a blanked off unused switch location on the dash. Now she can flip the switch up and the radio is fed 12v battery
power, flip it back down and the radio is fed switched ignition power like normal. Makes it easy to use the stereo while parked without turning on the key. A simple and useful project.
As long as I had the dash apart, I repurposed the old "Nav System" dash toggle that controlled the GPS in the old dash stereo I ripped out about a year ago. Now it switches 12v battery
power to power the new backup camera and its video display monitor that I installed so I can see what is behind the coach whether driving or parked.
Removed shower valve and bought a real one at the Home Despot. Bought a GFO outlet to replace the one that was in the dash that burst into flames.

I've been looking for years and finally got a nice kitchen faucet that fit the existing holes and fittings great. Easy to change but watch out for the little rubber inserts on the flair it fittings that might pop out and get lost under the sink. Got lucky and found the one that flew out. Added a 12" spout so it now reaches into the center of the sink. Yes it was twice as much as an RV faucet or one from the big box store but it is nice and fit perfectly with no mods.
https://www.faucetshark.com/T-S-Bras...1120-xs-ln.htm
Hope this helps folks with older MH's with two holes 8" on center.

Doing a walk around I saw one of the license plate lights was out. Didn't think too hard on it and went and bought a replacement 1.25" round push in replacement at O'reilly. Seems it should have been easy.
Well I didn't think how most car installations are in a steel bumper attached to the frame and a motorhome it's snapped into a fiberglass cap.
Yup when I pulled it out there was a power and a ground lead to the fixture. All the car ones ground through the spring fingers that hold it into the hole so they are single wire.
I tried searching all the usual suppliers I could think of. Ended up going with a Blazer #B165 LED. Cut the leads off the original one and soldered them onto the LED and then used some shrink tubing to seal and insulate the connection. Now I'm waiting for the other to go out so they'll match. The new LED is much brighter than the old dirty one is. Even if it was clean this LED would really outshine it.

Power Gear hydraulic leveling system. 19 year old motor rusted up, bad noises coming from the pump.
Motor sits on a plate with pump below in the fluid reservoir. You can see the bearing, it wouldn't turn.
Replaced the motor, bearing, seal on the pump shaft and cleaned up the plate.
On a gasser all this sits behind the front grill, everything gets wet driving in the rain.
Now it is the quietest it has ever been.

This is also an update to my Battery Disconnect thread.
So I had shut off my Batteries by pressing the battery disconnect switches. I thought I had turned them back on but a few days later I found my RV was no crank, no start, barely any battery juice, no aux at all.
So I recharged engine battery. Still no help.
There was alot of corrosion so the maintenance I did was to thoroughly clean the battery posts and the cables.
I used contact cleaner and a brush to remove the corrosion from the cable terminals and the posts. Worked very well. Then I applied CPC to all exposed metal to help slow new corrosion until I replace the battery. Also used electrical tape on the cable insulation to help protect them as they had some nicks here and there.
Cleaned & CPC'd all the hardware for the cables and reinstalled them nice and snug.
Got in the driver seat and it started. Yeah for basic maintenance!!
As I was doing this, I found a reason or potential reason for my original issue. Ill post it on another thread.

EMS-LCHW50 BYPASS SWITCH INSTRUCTIONS, I am attaching the instructions for the Progressive industries bypass switch kit but you can use your own switch to do the same thing all you need is a rocker or toggle switch and a way to mount it the switch mounts on the power input side between the terminal with the blue jumper installed and the white neutral lead this allows the power relay to energize when the switch is closed. Quote:
Originally Posted by CA Harts
Do you have information on how you did this
Intelitech battery isolation delay circuit so it actually charges house battery
Thanks
The original problem I was having was due to voltage drop at the ignition lead to the isolation delay relay, the blue wire on the relay needs to see 13.3 v for 12 sec before it closes the tombreta relay tying the chassis and house batteries together which allows the alternator to charge the house batteries. Due to drop on the ignition lead that is connected to the blue wire on the isolation relay the voltage never got above 12.9 v which would never allow the batteries to charge so I used the voltage at the chassis battery post in the front distribution panel and switched it on using a relay powered by the ignition lead , I drew a sketch that I am attaching the drawing does not show it but I added a 5 amp fuse in the chassis battery lead before the relay contact if you have any questions let me know.

If HWH their website is very helpful as are their tech reps via phone. Springs are pretty reasonable $ and not hard to do if you have a safe way to get clearance under the rig.
Wooden wedges placed between coils of an extended spring and retract the cylinder is a helpful trick for removal.
Reverse for replacement... clamp one end hook in a vise and insert wedges as you bend the other end from side to side extending the spring. Install on a fully retracted cylinder and then e tend to remove wedges.
Likely some decent photos if you search the forums.

How do I repair a broken automation spring? My driver's side night shade does not roll up. No spring action at all. The day shade works fine. Help!

Quote:
Originally Posted by flywithcoop
How do I repair a broken automation spring? My driver's side night shade does not roll up. No spring action at all. The day shade works fine. Help!
If it's a roller shade, there's a slim chance it's repairable. Over the years at our shop, I tried to repair them many, many, times. The first challenge is being able to access the spring assembly. On both metal and wood rollers, there's usually a small brad or rivet securing the end. These will have to be removed before you try to pry the end cap off to access the spring. The other end is just a cap with a pivot and doesn't need to be removed. Beware, if the spring is still wound, there can be considerable tension on it. Wear eye protection. The vast majority of the time when the spring pressure goes it's because the spring itself has broken. If the break is near one end, you can sometimes remove the short broken piece and re-anchor the end, then re-tension, and reinstall. Did you hear anything let go when you tried to raise it? If not, it might be the dogging mechanism is jammed. Repairs to this are also rare because of this is where all the wear takes place and the hole can get elongated or worn or the dogging cam shaft worn. However the most common symptom of a failing dog, is the shade won't stay down. Usually when we got a work order to repair a roller shade or projector screen
, I'd suggest it be replaced because being able to make an effective repair is so unlikely. Now, of course, if this was my shade, I'd be taking it down to look just because I always like to see if I could fix it. But that's me.

The passenger side door handle quit working on my tow vehicle. I ended up having to change out the interior door panel. While I had it apart, I put some sound deadening material on the door. I had one of my heated mirrors smashed when I hit a street sign on the passenger side in Mexico when a big bus forced me over too far. Going 50 MPH.
Inside was that motorized platform, and that particular brand had the 4 springs. It was ruined though so I checked the overstocked electronics businesses I'm used to checking and found some for like 5 bucks each. Bought 3, still have 2. Truck mirror platforms they were called.
Anyway, what I wanted to say is that the heater is a stick on thin sheet of aluminized foil with a heater wire between layers of foil that you'll need to peel off the mirror...maybe. If you do need to peel it off, note that when I had the new mirrors made, (cost all of $8 for a pair in Mazatlan) I just stuck that heater back on. And it stayed in place for years after. Didn't need to do anything special except keep it clean.

Looking to replace the beam type wiper blades on my 2021 Winnebago Adventurer 27N with either conventional or hybrid. The wiper arms have J-hook ends and the blade length is 800mm(32").

The J-hook on the wiper arms measure 8.5 mm wide, the space inside the hook is about 10.5 mm and the length of the hook is about 32 mm.

I have no idea how to size this when shopping for blades. Google searches are vague at best. These forums mention blades for lot of different coach builders, which use different sizes. I ordered Trico 67-324 from Amazon (because they state they are for RV's) and the hook is sloppy on the blade mount; the width of the slot on the blade is much larger than the arm hook and there is too much play on the inside (10.5mm) hook clearance. There are no adapters included with these blades.

The Winnebago manual has no mention of wipers. I called Winnebago Customer Care, and they told me they have no idea what size the wiper arms accept, but I could buy replacements by calling Mobility RV. I do not want replacements; the beam type blades do not make good contact with the windshield at the tips.

Anyone know how to size the blades? Recommended replacements? I would like to stick to buying at Amazon because, like in the case of the set I just tried, returns are very easy.
I can’t give you a specific measurement but there two size J hooks. You apparently got a wide blade J hook and have a narrow J hook on the wiper arm.

While I can't answer your specific question, I believe MH mfgs frequently change the type of wipers depending on what's available/price etc when they are building them. I have not replaced the wipers on my Precept yet, but on my previous MH that had the 32" long blades, I changed to 28" long which reduced the "drag" and "skipping" quite a bit. I had read on the forums that many had done that and were happy with the results. The 28" length cleans plenty of area for adequate vision. Here is a link to another thread and I'm sure there are others if you do a search.

I just checked the arm J -hook using a blade off of my Ford Expedition. The width appears correct (9mm?) but the fit is no good because there is too much slop inside the hook. So there must be more to it than just a 12mm and 9mm fit. So even going to 28 inch long blades, which are commonly available, does not solve the J-hook fit issue. Very annoying.

The blade length is the thing that really matters when shopping for blades. Any set of blades I have bought in the last 30 years comes with adapters to fit the different sizes and styles of clips. For our Vista we just buy 32" Trico blades on Amazon.

The adapter would be the most important thing for you. That said I bought 28” Rain X and I am happy with them. The two inch difference at the top and bottom made no difference in my sight line and I found the less surface area was cleaning better on the highway.
Take the old ones into Napa. They will order them if not in stock and most of the time it's only a day or so. They will mount them to the arms if you bring them in. Satisfaction every time.

When we need to replace our motorcoach's wiper blades we'll remove them and go into auto parts store or Walmart, was easy enough to match up size and there was adapters included for most any type of wiper arm. Where we live and do most of our RVing (4 corner states) we replace our wipers due primarily to dry rot, since they are rarely used for driving our rig during a rainstorm we just pick a medium grade wiper for every vehicle we own. Although I order most everything from Amazon, wiper blades are common enough to pick up locally wherever we happen to be, at least that is what we have experienced over several decades and dozens of vehicles, hope you find a set of wipers for your rig that fits your wiper arm properly.

LOL! I went with the Tricor 67-284's.

The box shows a pass thru rivet for the plastic part that connects to J-Hooks. And, it shows a second hole, with the box direction showing the bolt attachment like I have on our coach. BUT NO HOLE for the bolt, on the actual wiper!

Sure, if I was home I could drill a hole. Or more likely pop-out the pass thru rivet and use those holes.

At first I thought Tricor had missed the drilling the hole, THAT THEY SHOW the picture of with the bolt/nut attachment. So opened the second box, and same thing...

I do carry tools, and I do have a Dremel on board. But, drilling and grinding off a rivet - will certainly mar/scratch the paint. And yes, I can go buy a can of spray paint and touch that up...

But you know, it just does not seem right! As we have rain to contend with, and one of the passenger wipers blade is now falling a part - I moved the rubber insert from Tricor to the AM wiper... But want the new wiper bow, as they're new, and the I believe they will keep the rubber blade in better contact with the windshield.

Two steps forward, one back! And just venting, and sharing that in this Tricor 67-284 RV wiper - the boxes images/directions are not representative of the actual blade!

Be prepared with blue tape, a pair of needle nose pliers, and some patience. I've had to spend way more time then I expected installing refills. There's 2 long thin pieces of metal that go on either side of the refill, to give it strength. And I'd keep dropping those. So I learned to put them on either side of the rubber, tape them in place a couple inches back, maybe bend the holders hooks back a bit so they aren't too tight, slip the assy into the first section, remove the tape and then slide it all in the rest of the way. And then squeeze the hooks back tighter if needed.

BTW, I've been shocked, shocked I say, when I've looked at those wiper assemblies in autoparts stores or big box stores and found them to be freakin' $36 for two. And no inexpensive refills anywhere. Just the entire wiper assembly, in packs of two. I understand that the stores just want the extra profit for selling something the consumer might need 'right now' if a storm is coming but often as not the wiper assy on their car/truck/RV is in excellent condition and all that is needed is the refill blade. So a buyer tosses the old ones for no reason and they end up in land fills, still usable. Really burns me they do that.
I see they only go up to 29" blades now, those are $11.27 ea. HD refills $4.76 ea.

Have you tried torquing to 35 ft lbs, wait 45 min and retorque? That frequently cures Monaco wiper arm problems.

With 31" blades, there is a lot of drag and at 65 mph, there is a lot of air pressure against the blades at the top of the stroke, so after torquing the nut to 35 ft pounds, waiting an hour or so and re-torquing, it worked a couple of times, then stripped the remaining splines out of the arm. I have a 2023 Dutch Star 4369. First full winter storage question. I’m Debating if simply blowing out the lines only will suffice or if I need to fill the system with the RV safe antifreeze fluid. ? I do have it in fully enclosed storage.
Thank you for any kind suggestions

You're going to get all different opinions on this. As for my rig, I drain out the waterheater, drain the low point, blow it out with air and add rv antifreeze. It all depends on what makes you feel safe.

If you are stroring in an area known to threaten freezing temperatures, blowing out the lines, draining the tanks, and opening faucets leaves sink traps and shower drains untreated. Each retain water. Pour them full of anti freeze

I also add anti freeze to the black and gray tanks. That way, any residual liquid remaining in the drain hose gets diluted by anti freeze in the final purge

I do the blow/pink/blow method. Blow out the water, run antifreeze throughout, and then blow out the antifreeze. There's other things to consider; washer/dryer and icemaker and undersink filters; these all require special attention.

I would recommend using rv antifreeze. A couple of years ago, we winterized the camper blowing out the lines. We was going to be using the camper around the first of the year for a trip so we thought that would be easier. Found out some water did not get blew out for some reason. It didn't bust any lines or fitting. After that I will not depend on blowing out the lines. Another thing I have learned is to relieve the pressure and drain the hot water tank before switching the bypass valves. When pumping in the antifreeze I will turn the bypass valve to get antifreeze in the valve. Had water get trapped in one of the bypass valves and pushed the stem out of the valve. Luckly I was able to push the stem back in the valve and it has been good every since.

I agree. I don't do the second blow out but do drain whatever comes out the low point drains and leave all faucets open. In addition, I make sure that, while the system is pressurized with pink stuff, to flip the water selector to the auto-fill position so that solenoid opens and allows pink stuff to flow through that little loop. First year I didn't do that and that solenoid valve was shot the next spring when I de-winterized. I just assume some water was left in there...maybe not...but I want to be sure.

My rig is in my unheated shed and is therefore exposed to temps that can get to near -40F.

Since you are new, first thing is use Search. Most all of your questions have been answered hundreds of times.
If you have Aquahot, you must blow out with 40psi air, and then RV antifreeze. No other way. That's covered in your Aquahot manual.
And, I would think you do have Aquahot.

Based on current temps, I assume you have already winterized. But, here is my 2 cents. I have mine in an enclosed storage in the Galveston area. It is currently mid 20's outside right now. Admittedly this is nothing compared to what people north of us are seeing (like you in OK). I blew the lines out and poured the RV antifreeze in the drains and Splendide washer/dryer (spin cycle per manual). I drained my Truma water heater.

But, my plan next year is to go ahead and do a final sweep of the lines with antifreeze. It doesn't take that long, and I'd have a better peace of mind. If I lived up in OK, even with an enclosed storage (unless it is insulated), I would definitely use antifreeze. As others have said and as others have lined me out in the past on this forum, the air just doesn't do an awesome sweep. A good test is to sweep it with air then come back a few minutes later and see that more water comes out. You can keep doing that or just use antifreeze and be done. If only using air, unswept water will settle in low points and possibly freeze a fitting or maybe a valve and could cause damage. Yes, as someone else pointed out, be careful to use your user manual for your Oasis for special instructions. I've seen several people on this forum post about not winterizing their Truma Aqua Go water heater per the manual, and it cost them big time for something that is very easy to winterize.

What does your owner's manual say? Do that and don't worry.

But here are likely incomplete instructions:

Since you have an Oasis, you will need to pump RV antifreeze through the system. It will displace all the water. No need to blow out with air first (which requires filtration for the air or a oil-less compressor). Get full-strength red fluid out of every tap, hot and cold. Make sure it's enough to fill the drain traps, too. Don't forget the shower and outside shower. You might have a 3-way valve to make this easy or you might need to take the inlet off the water pump and use an adapter to connect the hose to the RV antifreeze containers.

If you have a washer or washer/dryer, a dishwasher, or an icemaker (or any combination) you will need to follow the instructions for each appliance. Compressed air won't winterize those lines, either.

Make sure all the tanks and low point drains are empty. If you have a black water tank flush, use that too. It helps to tilt the coach to the left a bit.

I use 5-6 gallons of RV antifreeze a year. Your coach might need 3, or 7, but you'll need more than one and fewer than 10. If you get 8 you'll probably have a head start on next year's supply.

Hope these ramblings are helpful.

(Edit) It appears that for at least some Oasis models, you can use the fresh water drain and optionally compressed air to winterize the unit *or* use RV antifreeze. See https://www.manualslib.com/manual/12...S.html?page=11 Find and use the manual for yours, though, to be sure.

Search is always a good idea, but the manuals are often a better source for information about winterization procedures. Also, the OP has an Oasis. Similar but not the same, so the procedures might differ.

For AH, though, from the 450DE Service Manual on p. 112:

"Please follow these instructions when winterizing the Aqua-Hot’s Domestic Water Heating System; reference Figure F1:
1. Completely drain the fresh water storage tank.
2. Disconnect the domestic water demand pump’s suction line from the fresh water storage tank.
3. Attach an adequate piece of hose onto the suction side of the domestic water demand pump.
4. Place the opposite end of the hose into an adequate supply of FDA-approved “GRAS” RV Antifreeze, and turn on the demand water pump.
Open and close all interior and exterior water faucets, one at a time, until only pure RV Antifreeze is present. Perform this procedure for both the hot and cold faucets.
6. Turn off Demand Water pump and remove the hose and re-connect the domestic water demand pump’s suction line to the fresh water storage tank."

The only mention of compressed air is in the Warning box:

"An FDA approved “GRAS” rated winterization antifreeze must be used. YOU CANNOT BLOW DOMESTIC WATER COIL OUT WITH AIR TO WINTERIZE AQUA-HOT." In other words, using compressed air is neither necessary nor sufficient.

I used the blow only method successfully for many years on my last rig. Last coach was much more basic. I would NOT trust that method with my DS or OP's Dutch Star. Reason being bath & a half, ice maker, washing machine, dishwasher, etc. These are all things I didn't have in my last rig. Many more water lines to worry about getting blown out.

The easiest thing to do, after you drain the freshwater tank, and the hot water tank, is to let the low point drain for several hours, then run RV antifreeze through the entire system. Of course, you have to turn the water heater bypass valve. For some odd reason my motorhome won’t draw from an RV antifreeze bottle. I drain the point drain for a few hours, then use an air pump to pump as much water out of the low point drain as I can. Then I blow air out of each fixture three or four times until nothing comes out. I start at the farthest point from the air pump location. Even if you use the RV antifreeze method you should still let the low point drain for several hours first.

I have always just blown out everything and just put antifreeze in the drain P traps.

It takes longer with the icemaker in the fridge and washer/drier as well as the 2 filters, but I don't have any antifreeze taste the next year. We cook and drink from the fresh water tank. If you don't cook or drink from the FW tank, use the antifreeze. Your choice.

The Aquahot manual is for the Aquahot...not for the washer / dryer and all other connections in the water system (hot AND cold).
Yes, using just antifreeze will likely work fine as it does displace the water. More thorough is to remove all "easy to move" water with air and THEN use antifreeze. Takes less antifreeze too as it's easier to know all hoses are filled with antifreeze when the flow transitions from Air to Antifreeze than it is from Water to Antifreeze.

But, the key part that many people mess up is you HAVE to use antifreeze as air alone won't move the water in the multiple coils in the Aquahot.

And, I didn't see that he has an Oasis as he posted that in response to my post.

And yes, all of the above is easily found using search. But, I also agree (and posted), to read the manual.

Agree you will see lots of different answers but different MHs require different procedures as does washers, ice makers etc.
You likely have Oasis heat and ITR specifically states that blowing out is not sufficient. So blow out first, if available is a best practice IMO and what I and many do, but then pump pink AF throughput the system.
Of course, drain tanks before. Read & follow the manual for winterizing.

Also, I had problem with water fill solenoids on washer after using alcohol based AF. Had to replace both and have switched to using propylene glychol based AF since w/o any issues. It's a little more $ and sometimes harder to find. I found it easy to order online and ship to home button the $ varies a .ot so worth shopping around which is EZ from computer vs chasing around.

This is the first year I did not pump antifreeze into the system. I built an insulated, non-heated garage at my house. I just blew out the lines with air and dumped antifreeze down the drains and in the toilets. We've had a couple days below 10 degrees. So far, the coolest my garage has gotten is 35 degrees.

We are building a fully heated and insulated RV garage with a "whole house" backup generator. Living in Michigan, we will store our DP from October through April each year, never exposing the coach to sub-freezing temps. The plan is NOT to winterize. Any concerns to the contrary?
Thanks.

Takes about $20 in material and 20 minutes...not worth the investment if the primary plan fails for some reason? Heater goes south, generator fails, etc.
But, to your point, if you are sure it won't freeze, then don't worry about it.

What's the cost to keep the RV garage heated all winter? My shop is heated, but I use it every day.

I live in New Hampshire. Temps go below 0°. I also have a Dutch Star. I drain, blow out and put in the pink stuff. I have never had a problem.
Don’t forget the following:
Hot water line to the front of bus
Ice maker and door water dispenser
Dishwasher if installed
Washer
Shower, (overhead, wand and save water return)
Outside shower
Take out water filter cartridge and make sure cup is empty
Put air chuck on black tank wash and blow out
Nothing to do to Oasis heater
Empty outside refrigerator
Take all food, to include cans
Any liquids especially medicine cabinets and shelves.
Irish Spring soap to keep out the mice.

I do the same in KC & don't winterize & I sleep like a kitten. Our temps are similar enough. I don't even have back up power. Truth be told only time my coach has ever been winterized is when I took in to Nappanee in December 2015. We too drink the water from the coach & I hated how long I was throwing out my ice cubes that had a pink tint. If you/I ever have some catastrophe you can always winterize.

I like most are a belt and suspenders kinda guy.

It's so much easier to completely drain and thoroughly blow out the lines. Then a few gallons of antifreeze, no worries.

Or wonder if something froze and failed somewhere.

We make a trip to the Memphis area for Christmas which is the last for the season. At our last overnight stop, I clean the black tank, drain both, drain the water tank, open low point drains and open all faucets. These are left open while we travel because I think you get a better draining of the systems from the jostling around while you drive.
We also have macerator toilets which I flush while on air, this draws the water level in the throat way down, so it takes less antifreeze to winterize.
I follow a detailed checklist I made for my coach, but basically blow everything out, pump antifreeze through the AquaHot, stools, antifreeze in drains, then leave all lines & faucets open. Takes about 2 1/2 gal. We sometimes get below 0* temperatures.

while on the topic of anti freeze. I filled a dixie cup half full of 50 below rv and marine juice and filled the other half up with water. It went down to 26 last night and it did not even begin to freeze.. Totally worthless post to most I know.

I use both. I drain the freshwater tank then use air and blow out the lines. Then pump RV antifreeze through all the lines, pour antifreeze in the traps and toilet then take it to a dump station and dump the holding tanks.

I live in Massachusetts and I'm planning a weekend trip 9-11Nov and a 30 day Florida trip 08Jan to 02Feb. Should I winterize now or wait until after the Nov weekend trip? Or can I just leave the tank heater on (although that sounds like a long time to leave those running). I believe the tank heaters cover the black and gray tanks... What about the fresh water tank?

I'm thinking off using the air pressure method .. does anyone make an inline pressure regulator so I can ensure I limit the pressure (I'm assuming it has to be less that 60 PSI).

I’d go ahead and winterize it. I use compressed air and RV antifreeze, but compressed air alone works well if you’re sure you can clear lines to the washing machine, ice maker, etc. I use a Porter Cable 6-gallon pancake compressor. It works well. It has an onboard regulator and I keep my pressure at 50 PSI. There are separate pressure regulator attachments available if you prefer that.
Use search. Winterization is a really popular discussion thread around this time of year.

Winterizing with antifreeze is an easy 20 minute job that cost under $10. Why not do it now if the forecast is for freezing temperatures? I sometimes do it 3 or 4 times a winter. On time I did it at an interstate rest stop on my way back to Indiana from Florida in February. Not a big deal after you’ve done it a time or two.

I face this decision every year because we usually camp trackside at the Formula 1 race down in Austin, Texas in late October. It often gets cold enough to winterize here in Colorado before the trip, forcing me to winterize, then de-winterize for the trip, then winterize again. It’s no big deal. This year, it has been warm enough in Colorado that I didn’t have to do it before leaving for Austin next week.

As an option, Steven & April, consider just draining all lines and leaving faucets and drain valves open to allow for expansion of what little liquid remains (if it freezes). Drain black and gray tanks and toilet. You should have a drain plug on the water heater tank as well as drain valve for fresh water tank. Additionally, in your wet bay should be two 'low point' valves for the hot and cold lines that will dump anything left in the system. Repeat when you return from FL and then add anti-freeze for the rest of the season. Just an option to consider.

We have a 2015 Newmar Ventana LE 4381. We are on the road. Yesterday, we got shut out of our rig because of the failure of the Trimark door latch on the entry door. Fortunately we had our cell phones, but not much else. We called a locksmith to no avail, understandably, because, as we discovered soon enough, the door was not locked. Something else was amiss. The local Newmar dealer service tech was kind enough to take our call (it's a weekend, y'all - no one makes house calls, Newmar is closed and our extended warranty provider is a joke (another story for another thread)). The local service tech asked questions about our situation -- the door handle was very loose with no give to it at all -- and helped us to understand that the door latch pinion (for lack of a better term) that inserts into the door jamb had failed. Our only option was to enter the rig another way. With our model, he explained that the only viable manner of ingress was the driver's side window, which, of course, was locked. Folks, we worked on trying to unlock that window for four hours. Without a sophisticated means of trying to bust the lock on the driver's window, we ended up having to break the glass. We'll be driving East today with plastic over a window, making all of us Newmar owners proud, I'm sure. The short of the long is, CHECK YOUR DOOR LATCH FREQUENTLY to ensure the pinion hasn't loosened up or REPLACE IT. If you still have the OEM door latch, it's a bad situation waiting to happen. Google the issue and you'll find this is not new news. It's a TriMark issue that is RV brand neutral. Why there hasn't been a recall is a head scratcher, but I'm looking at potentially $2500 plus for a new window.

Sorry to hear about your problems with the latch. I recently read about it elsewhere and that thread linked this aftermarket fix: https://www.latchfix.com/

I don’t know anything about the company, so I’m not endorsing it but it may be worth investigating.

Because a door latch is a safety issue, you should file a complaint with NHTSA. That’s how recalls get started.

Was the issue the deadbolt, or the actual latch? I have been temporarily locked out several times due the the deadbolt not retracting all the way. Several methods work, Had the best luck with slamming the deadbolt key while banging, I mean really hard, on the door in the latch area. I keep a little graphite on it now to keep it lubricated.


On another note, sometimes my electric lock on the latch fails. This is due to the contacts on the hinge edge of the door getting corroded or dirty. I just clean them with a little WD-40 and a rag (spray the WD-40 on the rag first) every now and then to keep them clean.


Sorry to hear about the cost of the window, that sounds ridiculously high for a double pain piece of glass. Wish you the best.


Hmmmm, I wonder what is the cheapest window to break out in this situation?



Safe and Happy Travels!

We always keep a window unlocked for this very reason. It has been discussed on this forum many times. Too bad you didn't pick up on it sooner. I bet you do going forward. I wonder if you can just replace the glass, not the whole window?
Leave the windows unlocked in the future. Nobody is going to break into your motorhome. The only thing locking the windows does is make your life harder when stuff like this happens.

The lock failure described and in the video for the replacement parts is a safety issue because it can lock you IN the coach ... think FIRE.


Safe and Happy Travels!
I ordered a new door latch from Newmar. It was about $600. People have posted "fixes" on line, but it just makes me so darned nervous to keep using the same door latch.

It's too late now but look or ask here first before ordering expensive items, like the door latch. Many have found suppliers outside of Newmar. The latch is quite a bit cheaper through TriMark. You can even get it cheaper in stainless steel through Summit.

If you look for that window, call Lippert first (they bought out Hehr) and see if they have the window.

On my old Dutch Star, I brought two wires from the switch into the electric bay under the driver's seat. I also had a set of keys in a lock box in the engine room. On my new to me Mountain Aire the size of the window is so much smaller that even my skinny DW would not go through. I have never been locked out yet. Anybody has any suggestions?
TIA
Agree I'm going to figure out how to replace the internal only deadbolt w/ an exterior keyed lock as that seems easier for entry than a window.
Many of us have the optional egress door. It would be really great if there was a way to put a lock on it that could be accessed externally.

The main issue with the Tri Mark lock sets is the cheap pot metal casting that's spring loaded for the door strike. There's a thinner area the spring goes around that eventually fails causing the latch to go into the strike due to the spring and loosing the ability to pull it back out via the handle.

I've replaced the lock 3 times on my 2006 Georgetown, once locked out and twice locked in. Locked in is easier to fix as the lock and trim around the door can be partially dismantled and the strike pushed / pulled back to open the door and fully remove the lock and remove the broken strike. Using the deadbolt to secure the door while traveling.

From the outside requires some ingenuity in getting a thin flat device into the strike area to push it back to unlock the door - nor fun at all an may end up marring the outside.

Leaving a window uocked to be able to get back in is the best option (lessons learned) to unlock the coach.

I also found that on the door contact point (small spring loaded contact point on where the door hinges together) can get dirty and cause it to not lock because it thinks the door is not shut correctly.

After being locked out one time, we got spare door keys for the trimark locks (2 different keys). We keep 1 set in each of our vehicles to ensure we will never be locked out again since we use the code to enter and never take the remotes or key rings. If you want a set of these keys, you have to contact Trimark. No locksmith I have found can get the blanks to make them. Look at your keys, get the code off of them and order them direct from Trimark.....and save yourself from ever needing to call a locksmith.

I did exactly that almost five years ago. Newmars price for those cheap plastic guides that easily break is absurd. I started by making a couple prototypes out of aircraft grade aluminum by hand. No issues, so I then had my S.I.L. machine up a batch. No issues since.

On our 18 LA the baggage doors have been getting harder and harder to close and when one was really getting harder to close decided to look at it. What I found was by taking the cover off and tightening all the loose screws and lubricating the locking assembly they closed so much easier. No adjustment to the latch just tightening and lubricating. Used white grease and some T-9 for lub. Since most of the holes for the screws to hold the covers on were loose went and put some wooden tooth picks and glue in holes and let it dry over night before petting the covers back on. With this the screws were tight again. Takes a couple hours but no more NEWMAR SLAM to shut the outside baggage doors.
Newmar Man

Good work Tom. On my 21 DS, one of the first things I did was adjust all the latches so I did not have to slam them too hard. Still tight enough where no water or dust gets inside though. I checked all my latch screws and cables and all were tight. I did this when I was installing emergency release cables on all outside compartments, but I will make sure I annually check these items.

Good idea. I have a CS and the amount of debris and dust etc., in my basement from (I think) where the flat floor slide arms retract is unbelievable. I thought the basement was weather tight. I never had side baggage doors until my current unit. I certainly can't say I'm very impressed with Newmar's design, adjustments, or latch choice. Overall I'd give them a "D" on quality baggage doors.

My first and best design enhancement was to make aluminum latch "riser/close" parts to replace the "prone-to-break" cheap plastic ones Newmar uses AND install them on all doors. No way any sag or "highway bounce" on the big doors can open them while going down the road now.
X2 on adjusting the doors. So easy to do. Had to weld an extension onto one latch to get it to shut properly. Love that solid sound when they shut properly.
Good tip. I seem to be constantly adjusting the latch on the coach side. I'll check these this weekend.

Two of the "alignment plate bin brackets" used for baggage doors with electric locks broke and the Newmar Parts catalog had them listed for $48 (Newmar Part # is 020658A). I contacted a fellow IRV2 contributor, friend, and Ventana owner and asked if he could make these on his 3D printer. The 3D printed version was not strong enough but he realized plastic cutting boards are about the same thickness and decided to fabricate them out of some old cutting boards using a drill press and band saw. His design included improvements to the original by increasing the thickness in a crucial pressure point and trimming some material away so the cable release had more room to operate. As an aside, one of my cable release pieces was frayed, and I did buy those replacements from Newmar (about $2.37 each). I would recommend checking those periodically and having a few spares on hand in case you find any that need replacing.

I installed my replacements today, and they look like they are going to work just fine. The photos below show the original broken piece (black) and a new one installed (white plastic), as well as some fabrication photos.

While I have never printed the latch part, the gears we have made cost about $2.40 each. My best guess is that a large roll of filament would make about 30-35 parts. FWIW, to the best of my knowledge you can no purchase the replacement gear for the step motors, requiring one to purchase a complete new motor for about $130.00. Hope this helps.

When I first took possession of my Dutch Star I had one door with a broken alignment plate bracket. After fabricating a new one similar to Eric's above and putting everything back together I very carefully adjusted the "Tight" doors and as Tom mentioned above in the first post, I lubed the latches with "spray white lithium grease". They no longer have to be "slammed" shut and a good push right next the handle will shut them with a nice solid sounding "click". I sure like the cutting board idea and I will cut them from that next time. (If another one breaks)

Regarding the alignment part, others have tried replacing with plastics which ended up cracking again over time.

I made mine out of aircraft grade aluminum. After making a small quantity by hand I had my SIL machine a batch for me. After having my large wet bay door fly open on a very busy I-90 due to a broken plastic alignment/locking part, I was never going to chance having that critical part break again. My aluminum version is now installed on all my bay doors.
Has anyone done this on their coach to protect the paint and make it easier to keep clean?

I had my coach ceramic coated. It’s expensive but I am very pleased with the results. The coach cleans up much more easily than before and I don’t need to worry about waxing it. For me personally, it was worth the investment.

I’m about to do this myself. Bought six bottles of Torque Details ceramic coating last fall. One small bottle has done our Jeep Wrangler, Chevy Equinox, two motorcycles and a golf cart. The stuff is incredible at keeping vehicles clean, and looks fantastic. Honestly, I think I’ve washed the Jeep and Equinox twice since October.

I have used 303 Graphene Nano to DIY coat toad and MH.
It is rather easy to use, has great durability and is forgiving when compared with many of the others. Many require 24-48 hrs cure with no rain/ dew possible which can be a challenge unless you have a large enough RV Bay with sufficient lighting.
I did a very light buff w dual action buffer, light cutting pad and a swirl remover as a paint correction, cleaning step before the coating.

The key to success with ceramic coating (and the expense) is the prep work. Your coach needs to be properly detailed and have any required paint correction work done before the ceramic coating is applied. The application of the ceramic is actually prey easy.

I am so glad you are happy with the final outcome after ceramic coating!!! As you mentioned, it is a very detailed process if done correctly, and even if it is a brand-new coach, paint correction is needed. Four out of five automobiles need paint correction prior to applying ceramic coating, now; imagine something the size of a moving billboard being painted; all coaches need some paint correction. I hate the term, "Covid-coach", what that really means is, "we found a reasonable explanation for poor quality escaping the process". The reality is that an excuse is all it really is. It is no surprise to anyone in the RV community that quality is struggling in the last few years and that includes the paint jobs. NIRVC recently did a few videos on this. The first is on paint quality standards, and the second is on ceramic coating. I have included a link for each here. The intent of these videos is not to sell, sell, sell! But rather; to continue to educate the RV community. We feel a well-informed consumer will ultimately make smart choices and be happier in the long run(AND.... Hold the manufacturers to a higher standard of quality_.)

I have a 2022 Newar Dutch Star 4081 - I have a couple of spots around the windshield where the rubber/caulking has peeled off - I am not sure how critical this is - there was one strip about 6" long that was fluttering in the wind on the highway - I was planning to cut it off with a razor when I get home, but it may be wonder is this something that needs to be addressed. Most likely what you're seeing peel off is the sealant applied to the retainer bead of the windshield gasket. This is one of those "just in case" steps the manufacturer uses to assure no water intrusion under the retainer bead which pretty well seals as designed. If concerned, you can reseal the bead with black silicone on clean rubber gasket. Realistically, it's more cosmetic then functional.

Ever since new, my coach has never made a clean swipe of the windshield. Living in California, we've only had to use the wipers on two occasions in 3.5 years, so it has never been a big issue. However, I would like them to work correctly.

Mine lay horizontal with the pivoting ends at the left and right outer edge of the windshield. In the photo below, the green area does not wipe cleanly. It doesn't chatter, just won't give a clean wipe.

Here's what I've done to date.....I replaced both 36" wipers with new blades and got the same result. It should be noted that the passenger side with the 36" blades always wiped cleanly. I found that the passenger "blade" was perpendicular to the glass and the driver's side was at a slight angle. I bent the arm to make the driver's side perpendicular, no help. My dealers' service department recommended that I put more of a bend in the arm, adding some pressure to the wiper blade. That made no difference.

I never cared for the fragility of the wiper arms with the 36" blades and changed them two months ago to 32". They swipe a path that's higher than my view out the windshield, so they work well in that aspect. However, I'm still getting a swipe that misses the lower corners, now on both sides.

The wiper arms have large springs that hold the arm against the glass. I guess they could be weak, but this has been an issue since new.

If someone has had the same issue on their Newmar with the same wiper setup, and found a fix, I'm all ears. My next step will be to add some sort of airfoil or wing to the blades to force them against the windshield while moving.

Are your arms pantograph type like a bus or straight arms like pickups? Your pictures show it has a straight automotive arm.
Depending on the amount of curve around the front cap and glass, they might be losing spring tension against that inside portion of glass.
Can you use a fish scale to measure the tension at inside sweep and outside sweep at the attachment point of wiper blade? Attach the scale, then pull until the blade begins to move.
