So I noticed the skylight caulk has turned brown and is starting to get some spider cracks on the sealant. I assumed it was just Dicor self leveling, but I've seen some other posts that suggest Surebond SB-140.

Before I hit up Newmar, figured I'd check in here to see what the consensus is. Also, is it good practice to replace the skylight if you're going this work, or do they last a while? We're going on 6 years with it, and seems fine other than usual scratches from branches and such.

What are you folks using to re-seal the skylight?

I used the Surebond SB-140. It is chemically compatible with the polycarbonate skylight material. This is the same sealant that Newmar used in the factory. Other sealants may cause crazing of the polycarbonate. No need to replace the skylight unless it is cracked.

It's SB-140. You CANNOT prep it with denatured alcohol, it will just damage the existing layer more. Have to do a clean scrape and replace, preferably with a few layers built up instead of the single pass Newmar does. SB-140 is not self leveling, you have to use a putty knife to spread it out across the surfaces.
I saw some videos of them using mineral spirits to get off the old stuff, that's still safe right? I do have a fiberglass roof, so not worried about the TPO stuff.

Here's some pics of my handy work. Few things to note, need two tubes of SB-140. Also next time I'll probably also just buy a new cover as well as it took FOREVER to clean the old sealant off both sides of the cover. The sealant is also super squishy and even after almost a week, feels like it's still wet. I don't like that.

Lastly, it's not easy working with that stuff, it leaves little stringy dribble trails everywhere. I'll probably redo this during the summer when I get back, as I don't think I did a great job and the single tube just barely got the edges covered.

It's a good thing I changed this when I did though, as I was removing the old cover, there was two spots where water was starting to get into the edge of the sealant.

You need another tube or two, that's insufficient coverage on the screws as it will harden and flex off after a couple months. You're not supposed to have stringy dribbles because you're supposed to put it on thick and spread it with a trowel. Normally you need minimum 4-6 tubes of SB-140 to do a skylight correctly. You applied that as if it was a self leveling sealant, SB-140 is NOT a self leveling sealant. It feels "wet" because you haven't spread it correctly.

Basically it needs to at least look like the original installation- but thicker. At least if you're planning to redo it you haven't really wasted much yet.

PS: I think Newmar dispenses it from 50 gallon tubs with a hand shovel :P

Good to know, thank you. All I had was the tip of the caulk tube to spread it around. It seems like even if you spread it around and there's a lot more that it'll stay pretty wet/squishy.

I'll plan on re-doing it this summer and will keep checking it every week or so.

I can’t figure out how to attach a picture to the post but this is from Rick Drinkwine at Newmar
Proper Sealants for Application
Plas-T-Coat…………..Metal or fiberglass roof
Surebond #140……..Rubber laminated to metal roof and all skylights
Carlisle #502-LSW….Rubber roof over wood base
Self Leveling Sealant
Silicone Saelant……..To cover butyl and other sealants;not to be used as the
main sealant
Parbond…………………..To seal across tops of windows,etc. on exterior
where silicone is not used

Newmar used double magnetic catches for many of the cabinets in our 2023 New Aire.

After a year and a half, we've had multiple catches fail. The pin retaining the magnet breaks - causing the magnet to get loose and the door to open while driving.

Last week, this happened to the lower bar cabinet behind the living room slide out, causing some large plastic pasta sauce bottles to drop onto the floor.

When we opened the slideout, we didn't realize those bottles where there - and the trim piece on the front of the slideout popped off, before we could stop the slide.

So having these catches fail could pose a risk while driving, depending upon what's in the cabinet and where the cabinet is located.

It's easy to replace the catches (BP33772AL Amerock).

And...

It's also easy to take some preventative action - by applying duct tape ontop of the catches to prevent the pins from popping out when they break - keeping the magnet inside the catch.

This is especially important for those catches which are located on the top or sides of a cabinet, where the pins can easily pop out when they break.

I found on my 2023 New Aire a bunch of these double magnetic door catches, but then discovered all the doors only had single metal strike plates installed on the doors. I was like "Why did they even bother?" I ended up buying a bunch so I could add the missing 2nd strike plates to all my cabinet doors. They stay latched much better now, especially the pantry...

Best,
-Mark

Adding the second plate also provides redundancy so that if one magnet does get loose, you can use the second magnet.

The downside of using both is that it can make it more difficult to open the door.

We've had a few doors that were too hard to open, even with only a single striker plate. Adjusting the magnet position (pushing it a little back into the cabinet) helped.

We've also purchased several extra sets of the plastic catches used on our bedroom closet sliding doors and the two ceiling exhaust vents. We've already had one of those break.

On my 2023 Newman New Aire my three vent panels keep dropping from the ceiling. It appears that the magnets they compression fit into the wood panel frames with some CA glue keep popping out of the wood. Once enough of them work their way loose from their sockets the entire panel drops.

I've tried prying them off the metal rail they adhere to, pushing them back into the wooden frame where it has been milled to hold them, as well as gluing them back in (thick CA). They still pop out as CA and magnets don't adhere well.

I am thinking of four possible solutions. One is to use strips of magnetic tape with 3M adhesive on the wooden frame (stapled). The second is to bore the magnet holes out deeper so they are flush with the wood and apply a super thin acrylic over them (will the magnets still hold the panel in place if not making physical contact with the metal frame in the ceiling?). Third is to try a coat of epoxy over the magnets and wood (may try this first). Lastly, is to punt and instead attach some velcro, stapling to the wood and some epoxy to the metal frame.

Anybody else having this issue? If so, what has worked to solve the problem in your Newmar?

Best,
-Mark

1st photo is a hanging panel after enough magnets came unglued, 2nd photo shows the 9 magnets that came out of the wooden panel pockets and stayed stuck to the ceiling bracket (the silver dots), 3rd is a close-up of a couple of the the empty magnet pockets where the pocket/glue gave way.

I think perhaps Newmar didn't think this magnetic panel attachment idea through all the way. They may need to go back to the old Southco latches on future builds even they they cost more than the magnets...

Check the voltage at the bulb when the lights are on. Lots of rigs are built with minimal size wiring, so voltage drops and lights are dim.

Lots of info about putting relays in to supply full voltage to the lights.

I realize that comparing my experience on a Thor Motorhome to what you can do in your Newmar may not be the same. I did replace both the low and High beam halogen bulbs with LED. First thing you will need to do is to take one low beam and on high beam out and find out what the bulb number designation is. In my case both the low and high used the H9 bulb. Then I searched Amazon for:

"h9 led headlight bulb"

which pulled up this one.

https://www.amazon.com/Termitor-H11-...1zcF9hdGY&th=1

You do need to be careful choices pulled up are often not clear about how many bulbs you get for the price. So, that really good price you see might only be on bulb. It is better if you buy in pairs. when you buy singles you can end up $10 dollars more per bulb.

I would also caution that some of the LED bulbs on Amazon are so bright, they have the potential to be a blinding hazard for on-coming traffic. This includes so called low beam LEDs. I had to really research which bulbs had acceptable watts for both low and high beams. Just because the bulb will light up three miles in front of me, I chose to be responsible and courteous, and I got lights that are much brighter than the POS OEM.
I agree, thats why I posted this question, I'm trying to sort through the hundreds of available bulbs for the ones that are the best.

Good for you for being responsible and considering oncoming traffic. I have used a large piece of cardboard out front to check the light cut-off patterns. It works great to align your lights.

Some of the cheap LED replacements are terrible. There are good ones out there, but usually expensive. They should be adjustable to get the correct light pattern for both high and low beam.

I have always been happy with Sylvania replacement bulbs. They work fine and last pretty good. Just make sure you're getting full voltage to them. Usually around 13 to 14 volts with the engine running.

Don’t get too geeked up about lights. I did a revamp on my lights a few years ago. I replaced the entire assembly. Very nice setup. The lights lite up the road for a change. We were on a trip in Arizona. Deer flew across the road. No more lights. Never even used them at night save for aiming.

I got the rig repaired and new lights. All is well. There are several aftermarket light suppliers. Great investment. I did not go led because there was more to it then just replacing bulbs. I did go with Sylvania advanced bulbs.

I checked that when I made the switch. Of course, the High Beam is blinding both with the original bulbs and with the LEDs. You can quibble about the LED being more blinding, but it is blinding with the old bulbs as well. The low beams had the exact same light pattern as with the old Halogen bulbs yes, the LEDs are brighter but do not direct the low beam into the eyes of oncoming traffic and are no brighter or blinding than the OEM LED lights on my Jeep.

A couple of things about headlights. First, when you drive in your car, you're pretty much sitting a few inches above the headlights and you're looking down the beam of the headlight like you would be looking down the barrel of a rifle. In this position, you can see the road better.

Fast forward to a Class A and you're well above the headlights and you're looking down at an angle from above at a beam that is well below you. This phenomenon is why the headlights don't look as bright. The headlights used in your Class A, are automobile headlight assemblies. My Dutch Star lights are from a Dodge Challenger. You don't hear anyone complaining that their Challenger headlights with halogen bulbs don't work. Typically, you drive a car even faster and don't have issues with the lighting.

Adding LED or HID to a standard halogen light housing (a housing where you can see the bulb by looking in) does not improve lighting. Yes, it will throw light everywhere and when pulling into a campground, you'll light everything directly in front of you, including the trees, like daylight. This is why people think the bulbs help. But....they don't change any of the lighting "down the road" where you need to be able to see at 55 mph to 65 mph.

LED or HID bulbs need to be "FOUSED". If you look at the new cars, they're using a concentrated lens in the center of the light housing (the owl eye looking lens). The LED lenses FOCUS the light down the road, giving the great lighting you see on new cars. Adding these same bulbs to a standard lens causes the light to "scatter" everywhere, appearing brighter.

A couple of solutions, if your new Bay Star has the focus lens, you could probably improve the down the road lighting with an LED bulb replacement. If you have the standard lens, your only help would be to add some driving lights, possibly where your fog lights are located. They can be directed further down the road and give you that ability to see at 60mph.

On my Dutch Star, I can replace the headlight assembly with one from a higher end Dodge Challenger. They offer the Challenger lenses in halogen, LED and HID. It would be a nice upgrade, but expensive. You have to buy the lenses for about $300 a piece and then the bulbs for another $200.00.

If you drive at night on a regular basis, add the Driving Lights or change out your lenses. I like doing projects and upgrading things on my coach, but I just couldn't justify the expense of changing the lenses since I've only driven the coach once at night in five years.

While I rarely drive at night, I am a huge advocate for daytime running lights and the safety they provide during the day. The quote/unquote daytime running lights offered on my Ventana are 2 LED dot lights under each headlamp. These 2 dot lights provide very little if any benefit to being a DRL, so I explored my options.

There is one aftermarket headlight assembly offered by Spyder lighting, however I don’t care for the look and would, IMO, diminish the look of the coach. With my options limited, I reached out to Oracle Lighting who is known for aftermarket HALO daytime running lights. They were able to add HALO lights to the 2013 Durango headlight assembly used in the Ventana.

It took a while to receive the lights but gave me time to build a couple of plug and play pigtail harnesses that would use the side marker light wire to power the DRLs.

The install was easy and with my adapters was a simple plug and play. There are 3 small screws/nuts that hold each headlight assembly to the front cap. When I was removing the original headlight assemblies from the coach, I was a bit surprised to see that all 6 of the little screws/nuts were very loose. Two of them were so loose that the nuts were about to come off. The problem was Newmar used regular nuts and not nylon lock nuts. Not a fan of “accounting” engineers who design as cheap as possible saving a micro cent over a correct design to actually hold items in place while rolling an earthquake down the road. <rant off>

Anyhow, pleased with the results.

That looks nice. I’d actually like to do something similar, but my Ventana (previous headlight style) is wired such that the headlights come on as DRLs as soon as the parking brake is released.

I am also a fan Oracle Lighting. I had them add custom LED rings into my tail lights.
Nice job. When I had my 2014 DS, I found a company that converted the rear taillights to LED, not bulbs, the entire assembly. It was a nice add on.

I went down that pathway originally. It was more difficult than I expected, and the consensus of most of the aftermarket lighting suppliers was that I would experience errors on the dash or with the functionality of LEDs. The LED rings don’t cause any issues.

Adding true LED light assemblies to a non LED vehicle can cause issues. One typical problem is hyper-flashing turn signals. The trick to resolve this is to add the proper load resister in the LED light wiring. If done correctly and in most cases, everything will be fine. Don, i did the same on my ‘17 truck and changed out both the halogen headlight assemblies and taillight assemblies to LED. Load resisters were needed on the taillights and both have functioned flawlessly for years.

The assembly was wired to avoid that issue, which I never had.

If I drove more at night, I would convert my headlight LENSES to LED, but just don't have the need to drive at night much.

Too strong and you'll tear the brackets out of the door. Too soft and door won't open or stay open.

Just wanted to let everyone know I found a great source for gas Struts. I needed stronger struts for my bed storage. I replaced our Sleep number with a tempurpedic which is much heavier. The original struts were rated for 80 lbs each And would not hold up the bed at all and it was very heavy to lift.. I went with 160 lbs each It now raises very easily and stays at full extension. 160 may have been a bit of overkill, it does take a bit of effort to start it closing but when it gets 1/2 way it closes itself. I don’t mind that a bit. I did also order struts and brackets for the hood. I went with 100 lb rated struts. That should hold at full extension without a problem. The place I found is Maxim Hardware. You can order almost any size you want and choose the effort that you like is increments starting at 30 lbs.

You need to be careful with installing too powerful of a strut. 160 pounds on the bed sounds good, but you might just tear the wood or frame apart.

I can guarantee that 100 pound struts on the hood will ruin the hinges and probably strip out the screws that hold the hinges on. Getting the correct rating takes some work and testing when you're adding struts to something that didn't already have them.

Be careful and mindful of the power these struts can produce.

The AV cabinet door above the driver failed on me today in that the anchors that recurve the hinge screws popped out of the wood door. I tried reassembling the hinge to the door but the plastic inserts just popped out again. Anybody had any success with a repair for this?

Not sure about this but add a couple toothpicks in the hole then insert the plastic screw insert. A little wood glue and then re screw the hinge back in. Or wood glue in a wooden plug and then screw the hinge in without the plastic insert.

Just thinking of a McIver fix. The toothpicks work on a door hinge the screws are stripping out of and this is similar.

Your cabinet looks like real wood, so, get a wooden dowel the same size. Glue it into the hole and trim it flat. Then drill a pilot hole and put your screw back in. This way you won't half to do it again. This works on chipboard also.

Gluing hardwood dowels into the cabinet face is the correct way. The cabinet is way too thin for soft toothpicks to grab well enough.


Be sure to drill pilot holes before you reseat the screws.

A quick fix is several toothpicks and a little wood glue. Remove the screws and get the plastic inserts ready to install. Put two to three tooth picks per hole in the cabinet with a little wood glue and reinstall the inserts. Let glue set and reinstall hinge.
Longer term would be to drill the holes insert proper size wood dowels then redrill hole for screws

Use a sheet metal screw that has deeper threads....maybe a metric one as they're a 1/2 size larger around......if you go with using a dowel plug, use a fine threaded screw.....Gorilla glue should be used, but you need to keep an eye on it as it cures, to keep the excess wiped off as it cures..and step drill up to final size......in my shop, I'd use the hinge as a template and a transfer punch to center the holes to be drilled in the plugs

The two holes are for the insert that takes the screw. I have had this happen on several of my cabinet hinges. The support strut puts extra pressure on the hinge, causing it to pull out. Newmar apparently uses lousy glue for this as I know of others who have had the same problem.

The easy fix is to re-glue the inserts in the hole. Here's how.

1. Remove the screws from the support strut and other hinge, if it has not popped out too, and set the door aside.

2. Remove the screws from the dowel-like insert plugs. You may have to hold the plugs with pliers when removing the screws. Don't worry about marring them, they won't show and any additional will just provide better glue "tooth."

3. Use a good wood glue (I like TiteBond III) and coat the outside of the inserts with it. With a toothpick, swab some glue on the inside of the holes in the cabinet frame. Do not put glue on the round hinge body hole or hinge body that seats in the hole; it will make future disassembly difficult.

4. Tap the insert plugs into the hole, covering with a paper towel or rag to prevent glue from squirting out. Don't ask how I know about this step. Seat the insert fully into the hole. Wipe up any excess glue with a damp paper towel or rag.

5. Let the glue dry per the manufacturer's instructions.

6. Reassemble the hinges to the cabinet frame.

There you have it.

Good luck.

Have had six cabinet doors with this problem, so far. Three were fixed by Newmar under warranty (tech used Sikaflex adhesive and gave me the rest of the tube for future repairs); the other three I did myself. Took a small piece of toothpick and stuck it in the pre-drilled hole in the door, then some glue and then screwed hinge back into door. All fixes holding.

this has happened to just about all of our cabinet doors that open vertically. The hinge that pops loose is always the one on the side of the gas strut that holds the door open. Newmar fixed a couple of them under warranty, I fixed the rest by putting a little dab of epoxy under the hinges and clamping them in with a long throat c-clamp with plastic jaws.

Yep...happened on several of the cabinets in our 2014 Ventana LE; always on the strut side. I think the strut applies additional pressure to the hinge.

I have fixed all of the hinges by removing the door (removing all the screws from the hinge), re-gluing the plastic screw plugs in place with Titebond Polyurethane and reassembling after the glue has fully cured (45 minutes). And, yes, it really does cure in 45 minutes.

Because the plug pockets are pretty snug, clamping really isn't necessary with Titlebond Poly; just be sure the plugs are tapped in firmly after gluing and don't reassemble until the glue has cured.

Javajelly: Once you get the plug out (or cut off, or whatever you have to do to get the hose open), consider putting a fitting on the hose with a removable cap, making life easier the next time. A convenient connector / cap combination could be a simple garden hose end with mating cap. I'm so lazy I hate to see YOU work.

Under no circumstances would I put that original plug back in, then go through the same effort to get it out next fall after it gets cold and windy. On the other hand, you could winterize while it's still 70 degrees out (or maybe not).

Thanks for your concern Ken. Actually I own a campground and have kids in school. Consequently I gotta get the majority of my camping in when it's cold at my home.

Seeing as how I'm in the Buffalo area that means the coach has to be heated or winterized from End of October to End of April. We always get flash frost in fall and spring.

So I winterize about 3-4 time a year. I really hate doing it in the cold. One I'm freezing and two it means I won't be camping for a while.

Don't cut it, just use mama's hair dryer and warm it up a bit. Me I use my $9 Harbor Freight heat gun.

Lastly, don't forget to do the hot water heater. You either bypass/drain or opt to have RV anti freeze in it. Just remember that when spring comes and you flush and sanitize the system.

Didn't need the heat gun this afternoon. All winterized.

Have a HydroHot so no water heater.

Couple of hiccups. First, I have a hose roller w/a check valve. I didn't think there was enough of a gravity drain when retracting so I blew air in first.

Second, I have a Norcold w/water dispenser. Did forget to run antifreeze through that. Had to go back and run it through after remembering. Also, the directions Norcold gives in the manual doesn't cover the optional water dispenser which has a different valve set-up in the access door.

You need to detach the ice maker but, not the water dispenser.

Finally, the pump pushed antifreeze back through the filter housing. I did take the filter out first. It didn't occur to me that the pump would push back to the filter housing when other faucets are closed. Not a huge deal but, a waste of antifreeze.

Trying to adjust the DS outside mirror and removed the cap at the bottom and loosened the nut inside but could not move the arm father out. What am I missing? I saw the hex nuts above but I want to move the mirror father from the side of the MH. Thanks

I assume you're wanting to move the arm farther out where it attaches to the bracket on the front cap. You're on the right track, just loosen the nut, if it's stuck try a rubber mallet or some method to bump the arm to crack it loose without any damage. There usually aren't any set screws in that joint. Once you get the arm out, you may need to loosen the set screws on the mirror joint to adjudt the angle of the mirror housing.

That mirror uses a cone shape insert over the bolt. As you tighten it, the cone really locks the mirror up tight. When you loosen the bolt, the cone doesn't necessarily release. A rubber mallet or a good whack with your palm will get the cone loose and allow the mirror to move.

I have a method when I adjust my mirrors. First, I imagine a string running the length of the coach, touching the sidewall and protruding past the front mirrors. I set the mirrors just the other side of the imaginary string, maybe adding an inch.

Once the arms are set, I adjust the mirror heads. I set the mirror glass where I want it. Often that leaves a big gap between the glass and housing on one side. I turn the housing until the glass is even on both sides. This may take several adjustments to get to that point. It helps to keep critters out of any big gaps. Once that's done, I make sure they are vertically straight, then tighten.

I know there is an aluminum roof frame under the fiberglass roof and was wondering if anyone has used that for the ground plane. It looks like it is a welded unit for the full length of the coach and might just work if I can find a way to get a ground strap from the framing to the antenna mounts.
Has anyone run across this issue or have any ideas?
Also, any pics would be great if you have any..



Thanks in advance for any help with this issue,
James

I would think it would be similar to installing an antenna on a roof rack..
But this is why I am asking questions, because I am fairly new to ham and have only used the UHF/VHF bands on my mobile. I really want to set up a ham shack in my house (coach) and I know there are people out there that have done this but the information is either very old or limited on what I can find on the subject.. Running the coax and finding ground plane is the tough part of this adventure.. :-)

You're throwing HF in the mix, which is an entirely different scale than V/U. HF is difficult on an RV - it's big, but it's not a groundplane like the solid metal surface of a car or truck. Problem with using the framing is they'll act more like radials than a plane, which means you'll have RF current and voltage nodes all over the place. That translates to potential for EMI and RFI inside, and also weird resonances that can affect the tuning of the antenna. Not saying you shouldn't try it, because not having radials or a counterpoise creates it's own set of problems that are generally worse. This is best approached by deciding what capabilities you want to have - mobile, stationary, what bands, what power levels. Before you go all-in on a solution, some testing with a mockup antenna in the proposed location can reveal whether it's a viable idea or not.

I'd be tempted to do two or three things....
Get a UHF/VHF antenna that doesn't require a ground plane like a Comet SBB5
I have one on my truck and wouldn't hesitate to put it on the trailer.
EHAM has some write up about it.
SSB5 on Eham

Possibly a screwdriver antenna for HF, but as was stated above, there will be a lot of metal nearby to create add reflections that will interfere with tuning.

I realize it's not convenient however a ground mounted vertical on a pole in a tripod with a counterpoise with as long of wire as space allows, or a G5Rv hung from a tree (read "L" or inverted V) would get better xmit/reception. You'll still need a tuner though. Military fiberglass camo net poles are easy to pack, strong and will get the peak of the antenna up, BUT not the best choice if it's windy.

BTW, if you don't have one, a VNA (vector network analyzer) is a Very handy tool for tuning and other diagnostics.

Mark,
I was thinking of using a screwdriver antenna (maybe Tarheel vertical) for the HF side of things and will only be pushing 100 watts max on the coach.. If I end up where I can set up a external antenna like a wire that would be a whole other option.. But most of the time I am in RV parks or State Parks with limited room for such things.. I would appreciate any feed back you might have on this..
James KJ5FAU
New Caney, Tx

OK, nominal power and performance. The issue with putting any antenna on an RV much less HF is clearance. You're already 12ft plus to roof level, adding an 8ft long pole on the top is a quick way to trim trees, find low bridges and power wires. Putting the antenna alongside the body is problematic because the structure will both detune it and impact efficiency. I have a long time ham friend that was full time several years. He ran a screwdriver antenna on his Bounder, liked to do HF APRS underway. This sounds kinda funny but he had the antenna mounted horizontally from the top of his roof ladder facing backwards. He pulled a toad so having this rearward protrusion wasn't a clearance issue, and the thing actually worked pretty well. So depending on your expectation of performance you can come up with a few different schemes that could work out OK but it might take a few stabs at it to find it. I've been running HF mobile for decades in my cars and trucks but so far I haven't been motivated to go through all that for the RV. Driving the RV takes far more attention than pointing a car down the interstate and adding HF mobile to the mix is too much of a distraction for me. There's nothing better to wile away highway hours than working a CW contest or working some giant pileup but I guess I'll save that for car trips. So I've skipped any HF mobile for the RV, concentrating on fixed operation after arrival. I've always loved to work portable HF when camping or traveling and since the advent of SOTA/POTA I'm having a blast with that. Sometimes one has to be a little more discrete with antennas depending on the campground or park but I always make it happen.

Mark K5LXP
Albuquerque, NM

I would offer, having been around this block a few times, having an HF antenna on the RV for stationary operation is a bit of a handicap. It's the lowest common denominator for performance, it's expensive, and an opportunity for EMI/RFI unless you get lucky. Contrasted to an antenna, or antennas not limited to mobile performance you pluck from a basement compartment, and can be placed at or far away from the RV as needed/possible. Yes, there's a convenience aspect that may have priority, but just planting the seed that convenience comes at a cost. Establish your operating goals, then work backwards from there to arrive at the antenna solution. Versus deciding on the antenna solution and having to accept whatever it offers.

Mark B.
Albuquerque, NM

James, Newmar motor homes have at good ground plane built into the roof. I have a screwdriver on the roof of my Ventana and it works great with close to a one to one SWR match on 80-10 meters. I ran two flat copper straps from the antenna base into the underlying aluminum with two stainless steel screws and applied a sealant on the screws. I'll attach a photo of a Newmar being built in the factory showing the inside of a roof and a photo of how I connected my antenna to the aluminum in the roof. I have more photos on my QRZ page. There are a couple of ways to locate the exact center of one of the roof members. If you look on the roof early in a morning with high humidity you can easily see the outline of all the cross members. The other method is to use a metal stud finder. Hope that helps.

The mirror is probably your best bet although I don't know how you'd install an NGP antenna to it without drilling anything. You also don't want the antenna rubbing on your paint anywhere or getting smacked by bridges.

We just installed a Firestick NGP 3 ft antenna with the same side mount to fiberglass that the Safari trek above used. ON the 4369, this involves unscrewing the wooden panel behind the drivers side window shade and reaching arm deep up in the front cap, drilling two holes from the outside and blind installing the two nuts up inside the front cap. Tedious. Make sure you mount the antenna far enough forward above that window that you have enough access armpit deep in the front cap. Working with an expert, we never got the SWR tuned below 2:1, likely due to limitations from the NGP solution.
Does any have the optional flag pole holder? Wondering if it is a worthwhile addition.

For several months I’ve been looking for an easy flag pole mount for my 4018. On my previous coach I had a ladder making flag mounting easy but the DS just doesn’t have a good spot.
I bought a piece of 1”x20” square stock and mounted it to my hitch with a 2” square U bolt tilting it out away from the coach a few degrees. Then slipped a 11/2”x5’ piece of PVC pipe over the square stock and drilled a hole through the PVC and square stock about 4” from the top and inserted a bolt just to keep the PVC in place. My 18’ Fiberglas pole fits in snugly. As long as I don’t use a huge flag or fly in high winds, the pole shouldn’t touch the coach.

This is what we use. Has a pair of suction cups and an adjustable flag mount. Comes complete with flag from a vendor in Florida.
Works great and even heavy winds do not bother it.
I have Flagpole Buddy on the ladder with 12' aluminum telescoping mast. Super easy to put up / take down. They have other mounting options if no ladder.

On our 18 LA we did get the flag pole holder and then had Newmar send us a Newmar flag. With a little wind it does get in the way of opening and closing the door. Would suggest it be skipped from order of coach.
Newmar Man
We like ours and would do it again. The flag holder is stainless and removed for travel. When removed you hardly notice where it fits on the body.

I’ve always liked to fly a flag at home and continued doing so on my house on wheels. I did get the Newmar flag pole holder and after trying it I agree it is not located in a good position. I had a friend modify the pole holder part so that the flag points 45 degrees closer to the direction of the coach. I figured this would move it out of the door way. That did work but after seeing that I thought pointing in the same direction as the coach would be even better. I’ve given my holder back to my friend and asked him to rotate it another 45 degrees.

I’ve also ordered a new flag and pole. My old pole had been sanded and revarnished many times and has aged to to point it needs to be retired. The flag was made out of fairly heavy material and marketed as being good in high winds. I ordered a new one made of a lighter material.
Last week, I was talking to a fellow with a 2018 Dutch Star with the flag option. He was standing outside of the door and he seemed annoyed that his flag repeatedly was hitting him in the face.
Looking for a good deal on Newmar Bay Star mudflap tow guard

Had to back into an elevated concrete pad from a gravel access drive. Dug the 94" mud flap into the gravel. Bent the steel tube protection bar. Straightened the bar out with the help of the RV park's maintenance guy, using his ATV's mounted wench. That bar is fairly well re-aligned now. The NEWMAR mud flap damaged too much to repair. Unbolted it from the rig.

Reading old irv2 blogs that are too old to comment on; I found lots of folks who prefer the flap off. They cite less debris on their toad as the main reason.

I'm aware of the "controversy" over the benefits/problems with the mudflap at the rear of the coach. Just adding my recent experience:
Saw something on the road, too late to avoid. Looked like a 2 ft long piece of shiny metal. Sounded like my left inbd rear tire hit it. Not able to pull off highway to inspect. Drove about another hour, watching the TPMS closely, incl on the toad. No problems noted. During my rest stop inspection, discovered that an aluminum tube, similar to a piece of folding chair frame, but heavier, had impaled the mudflap. (Why didnt I take a picture?) Had the mudflap not stopped it, I tremble to think what damage it would have caused to the CRV, especially if it hit the radiator. Removed said tube; now have quarter-sized hole in mudflap.

Lesson? Maybe they help, maybe they don't. Roll the dice. (I'm keeping mine on.)

I had a similar situation where a tire shredded in front of me and I had nowhere to go due to vehicles on each side. The carcass hit the front of the coach, ripped off the genset exhaust and both items went underneath and really bent up the mud flap. The mud flap ended up looking V shaped instead of straight across. My toad came out unscathed.

I think they are talking about the full width mud flaps you sometimes see under the rear “bumper” of a motorhome, not the flaps that come standard behind each wheel. The controversy is whether they kick up more stuff than they stop. I have elected not to use one but instead I extended my factory rear flaps behind the rear tires so they are closer to the road (about 2 inches of clearance). On the road they blow back some but there is a real possibility that the flaps can hit the ground on bumps that compress the suspension significantly. So far so good.

We're heading up the Alaskan Hwy and have been advised to NOT use my mudflap, due to it throwing rocks onto the toad. Anyone have any experience with this? Also, where would I store the thing if I removed it-the basement is pretty full now. Wonder if I could somehow tilt it upward into a horizontal position and wire it in place back there?

We have Essex which in 2014 did the Alaska trip and a lot of Canada. More then 2,500 miles of the 10K trip were on secondary and gravel roads and it was our tow that got the worst of the rocks. Don't think the Newmar mud flap helped or hurt the rocks from hit the tow. Two travelers with us but clear heavy stick on plastic and they had very little rock chips. Will need something to cover windshield from rock chips also on tow. We did get a couple good rock chips on the coach but at almost all RV parks had someone who would do rock chip repairs for between 40 to 50$ and would suggest you do so because some who didn't had crack go all across windshield. Great trip and one you be pleased with the great sites every day. Do take the trip but but be aware of the poor road conditions. If you see a cone or marker on the side of the road there is frost heave there which is like a speed bump and slow down. Be cautious of the shoulder of the road because of high crown. Stay more toward the middle of the road when safe to drive there.

Washing your RV?
I'm new to this and have never washed something so large. Advice would be appreciated in terms of products and techniques. Thanks!

There are several options for RV washing. The first is to wash it yourself. It’s really no different than washing your car, but you’ll need a ladder and a sponge/mop with a long handle. I use automotive car wash products on my RV. I prefer the products from Adam’s Polishes. You may find a self-serve car wash or truck wash that has bays large enough for your RV. There’s one relatively close to my house that’s nice to use when returning from a trip.

The next option is to use a truck wash service like Blue Beacon. I use these occasionally, especially if I’m on the road and I’ve driven in dirty conditions. They’re available at selected truck stops across the country. They aren’t great, but they remove the majority of the dirt from your RV’s exterior. There’s almost always a line, so the process takes about 30 - 45 minutes. It’s about $40, depending on the size of your RV and the options that you choose.

The third option is to hire a professional RV detailing service. I do this occasionally at the start of the season. In fact, I’m having this done on Saturday. I’m scheduled for a wash, polish, ceramic coating, and new roof sealing. This is obviously not cheap, but it makes sense to me to have it done periodically.

I just prefer to wash the coach myself. It takes me 2.5 hours to wash and spray wax. Yes, I'm moving pretty fast.

I have the following:
Pressure washer (Ryobi 1600 PSI)
Foam sprayer
Brush or lambs wool pad
Extension handle (get the one at Lowes in the paint section)
DI rinse (for a spot free rinse)

As for wax, I hand wax mine once a year and use spray wax while on the road.
Most (what I would call non destination) parks do not allow washing at your site.
For those, I've never had an issue just washing the front.
Some large RV parks offer a mobile washing and detailing service at your camp site. I had this done once at a park in Arizona and it was nice.

I recommend a foam cannon. I have a cheapo from Chemical Guys, and it is used with the garden hose. I spray the coach down with the garden hose, then spray it down with the foam cannon, attack it with my Marry Moppins wool pad on a telescoping pole & bucket of clean water, rinse & call it good. Sometimes I hand dry it. If your wheels are a polished & sealed aluminum product keep harsh wheel cleaners away & use only soap & water. Let's not get into which car wash soap to use as there are a zillion products & they are all good. I use Meguirs only because that's what's at Costco in a gallon jug. I use a lot of soap with the cannon.

You probably have Diamond Shield installed like we have on our 22 SuperStar.

To ensure that doesn’t get messed up I reached out to them for approved products along with going through the paperwork provided.

I’m using their wash for now since they had it in stock.

They recommended either Mothers or Meguires wax products. I’m using the Meguires ultimate liquid wax with a Ryobi 5 inch 18 volt buffer at 3800 rpm to polish.

The other product for the diamond shield is 303 Aerospace protectant which they approve for use.

Use a lamps wool mitt or the microfiber mop type on an extension pole to reach the higher areas - no brush type on the paint.

Our outer wheels are polished so just some dawn in a bucket to wash those.

I agree with what the others have said. I have a water softener, so my tank water is softened and reduces spots. I hook my pressure washer to my coach for both water and electric (generator on). When I do a good job, it takes 2-3 hours.

There’s a Mega RV wash location just off I-95 in Virginia that I’ve used in the past. They use reverse osmosis water to prevent spots and have options for brush or touch less washes. It’s also a Harvest Host location so makes a stop over and wash convenient.

I believe you are asking for self wash tips and you have received several that will work well. If you do it yourself, you’ll like the extension pole idea with a lamb wool pad and rinse of with softened water. Wax or polish periodically except for the front, do it more often. Storing indoors helps me a bunch.

Oh yeah, don’t forget to clean the roof and check caulking while you are up there. Be careful.

I adopted the principal years ago of NEVER using a brush on my RV. Tiffin actually has a sticker on their new motorhomes stating that. I use sheepskin pads for cleaning and do my final rinse with deionized water. Once a year I do ceramic coating. I have the advantage of a large RV garage where I have scaffolding so I don't need to work off a ladder. For on the road I have a foam cannon and a power washer along with the water deionizer.

I have two of the 5 marker/Identification lights on the front (up top) burned out. The ones at the outermost corners are ok. It’s two of the three center ones that are out. They appear to me to be LEDs, so I’m surprised they have failed.

I don’t readily see how to open the lens to replace anything. Do you have to rip the fixture off and replace the whole thing?

Secondly, I think I’m still legal as the two outermost markers are lit.

We have a 2017 Bay Star with the BriteTek roof. The roof membrane looks fine, but I am seeing some cracks on the sealant around the sky light over the shower. I guess it also time to reseal everything else, antenna holes, vents etc. Just wondering if I need to take off the old Dicor first, if so what tool works best. I am not sure how I would scrape it off the seem where it is screwd down. I see the posts for Enternabond, I don't think I am ready for that yet.

How much dicor will I need (its 35ft)? I have never used it before. The skylight seal looks different, is it also Dicor, and should I remove it first before resealing?

I also have a 2017 Baystar Sport. I replaced all the sealant at the skylight last year due to excessive amount of cracks. I found a 1” plastic putty knife works best for existing caulking removal. Using a metal one is too risky to damage the roof. I believe I used two tubes of self leveling Dicor. I suggest you watch several YouTube videos prior to performing any work.

X2 with Ranger John.
I replaced the dicor caulking around the skylight last year. I also used a plastic putty knife only removed the loose dicor and the dicor thatwas easily removed. I did not remove the dicor completely to the BriteTek, then I cleaned the dicor an the immediate BriteTek with alcohol (the alcohol dries quickly). After that I applied the new dicor over the remaining old dicor and about 1/4 inch of the cleaned BriteTek.

I would use the plastic razor and peel off the old sealant (lots of work). Clean with alcohol well, put a small bead of Dicor right at the edges to seal and all screw heads. Then, a couple days later post dry, seal with Eternabond tape over the top to make it all look nice and clean and seal for rest of ownership. Overlap the corners with the tape.

My whole RV top only took two 50' x 4" roles at about $50 a roll. Well worth the investment. Applying the tape to a sunroof should take 30 minutes.

dnhxx- Having done roofs on my 4 RV's on 3 different occasions, I was told by Newmar to use the Dicor self leveling sealant on all roof penetrations except the shower skylite- Dicor will have a chemical reaction with the type plastic in the skylite. For caulking around the bath skylite they recommend Sikaflex 252 as it will not react with the plastic.

thanks all. I went on the roof to really look things over,the seal around the skylight, definitely needs to be re done. Newmar told me to use skylight roof sealer part #23310P , which is SureBond SB-140 Skylight and window butyl sealant. I believe I will have to remove the old stuff before putting the new on. There are only a few other areas that have some minor cracks, so maybe just one tube plus a spare is all I will need. I am not sure if I will put the Enternabond tape over, as the dome may need replace in a few years.

dnhxx, We have a 2015 Ventana and it is about the same size as your coach. I cannot go up on the roof for health reasons, so last year I paid our local RV shop to go up there and inspect the AC’s and all opening on the roof. They used, IIRC (memory at this age is suspect), 11 tubes of Sealant. While they were up there I had the AC’s cleaned out.

Just finished resealing my skylight. DON'T use Dicor. Use the SureBond SB-140 for chemical compatibility with the skylight material. This is what Newmar uses. I scraped all of the existing SB-140 sealant (lot of work), cleaned with alcohol & applied new SB-140. I used two full tubes with none left over. All other roof penetrations use Dicor.

Winterizing ElectricRefer
Hello!

Using coach over a cold weekend - will need to re-winterize coach since we're returning to colder weather tomorrow. I'm unclear on best way to ensure I have antifreeze in the ice maker in the refer.

Thanks in advance for any advice!

If it is winterized currently, I would suggest closing the valve under the refer in the basement
area. If you close the valve, there is no need to re-winterize the refrig since the pink stuff would stay in the lines leading up to and including the water dispenser and ice maker. Same with the washing machine if you have one...close the hot and cold water valves to the washer before de winterizing and it will remain winterized.

If you have already de winterized then I think you will need to push the pink stuff through the water lines and ice maker again. I would start by pushing the pink stuff through the water lines, then, if you have a water dispenser, allow the pink stuff to get to there, then leave the system pressurized and make a couple batches of ice. Good luck

Following the winterizing directions in the wet bay was easy enough and I know the water lines to the faucets & toilet are winterized but the ice maker & washer was a challenge.

I read tips on winterizing and it seems there are different ways that work and I'm hoping what I did falls in that category. For the ice maker, I made "ice" with the antifreeze. A cycle of real ice popped out then the 2 batches were clear slushies. I left the fridge on overnight but turned off the ice maker & this morning the slushies were less slushie & more frozen but not as hard as the real ice. Of course, the temp in the freezer was close to zero. I thought I'd make another batch of slushies to be safe.

For the washer, I ran a cycle on cold until the pink stuff showed up in the drum, then cancelled & spun. I repeated that for the hot water.

This is how the former owner winterized but she also ran the Oasis burner & furnace set at the lowest temp last winter. We really don't want to do that but could for the coldest nights. Our coach is at home & in her own garage with 20amp so it'd be easy enough to do.

Have I missed anything?

Did you hear the pink stuff being drained though the drain hose? Mine is noisy and pretty easy to hear...

Many washer drain hoses make a giant loop from bottom of the washer up to the top of the drain pipe. At the bottom of the loop and at the bottom of the drain pipe, water will sit. You need to evacuate enough pink stuff to get the water out of the bottom of that loop replaced with pink stuff.

The drain pipe is easy to winterize 'cause you can just pour pink stuff down the hole.

Your washer plumbing may be different, but I'd evacuate pink stuff just to be sure.

Did you hear the pink stuff being drained though the drain hose? Mine is noisy and pretty easy to hear...

Many washer drain hoses make a giant loop from bottom of the washer up to the top of the drain pipe. At the bottom of the loop and at the bottom of the drain pipe, water will sit. You need to evacuate enough pink stuff to get the water out of the bottom of that loop replaced with pink stuff.

The drain pipe is easy to winterize 'cause you can just pour pink stuff down the hole.

Your washer plumbing may be different, but I'd evacuate pink stuff just to be sure.

You didn't say what year of Dutch Star it is, which would be helpful; however there should be a water pump switch in the water bay backboard and inside the coach in maybe a couple places... bathroom, and maybe on the panel where the energy management system is. The 12v system needs to be in the "use" mode as opposed to the "store" mode. My 12v store switch is on the energy management system panel, over the passenger side dash; but that is for a 2000 Dutch Star.

Give us more information on model year.

BTW... many of us don't flush antifreeze throughout the whole water system. We drain the hot water heater, water and sewage tanks and blow-out the water piping with air. And then just use antifreeze in the traps and any other low points that won't drain completely.

The Sanicon pump if connected to the 3" sewer pipe can be disconnected after the black tank is emptied.
Here is info for the rest of winterizing coach.

Snow and cold temperatures advice for Newbie
I will be flying out to Minnesota to bring my Essex back to Montana and being a Newbie I thought I would reach out of some advice.
1) Do I keep it winterized and stay in Hotels?
2) Is there a problem keeping snow from building up on windshield?
3) What to expect if we get snow on the highway
4) Any other input or suggestions would be appreciated.
Thanks Tom

I need to bring my Mountain Aire to Moscow Ia in January. I need to winterize it. I have never done this. What do I need to do???? Can I drain the unit and still run the oasis heater or do I need to install rv anti freeze?

Are you staying in the MH in Moscow or just leaving it there where it will be parked in the cold? If you are staying in it you don't need to do anything. No winterizing would be necessary. If you're leaving it in the cold then the safest way is to run rv antifreeze through the entire system. Don't forget the ice maker and the washing machine.

Unfortunately it is getting close to the time of year that I have to put my Coach away for the winter.

Keep waiting for the year I can head south for the winter, but we're not there yet.

This is the first year for storing this coach.

I understand the winterizing of the water system from having trailers, had a black flush on that trailer, so I'll remember that part too. Washing machine is the only new item to learn about, no dishwasher or ice maker

As for other stuff

When I park it, should I dump the air and put it on the HWH jacks? or just park it.

Parking on gravel, tires will be covered, should I put anything between tires and gravel?

Should I take all batteries out, coach and chassis? or is the solar charger enough to keep the cold from killing the chassis batteries?
I used to remove battery on TT and put it on a smart charger in basement at home. Can do same with coach batteries.

We used to put dryer sheets throughout the trailer and never had an issue with mice, so plan on doing the same thing.

Was hoping to leave all the camping gear in the coach.

Was going to top up the fuel and propane. Is there a recommended additive for Diesel fuel when it is stored

Any advice is appreciated, still got a few weeks and a couple of short trips.

Thanks

I've read the tires should be parked fully inflated on a dry surface. Even though it'll be on gravel if the site is low and the gravel remains wet I'd park it on a 2x? to keep them high and dry.

For long term storage I always remove the batteries then store them connected to a smart charger. Has always worked for me.

My son-in-law tried dryer sheets but they didn't work for him. The previous owner of my trailer stored it in a barn year round. He stuffed steel wool into any little opening the mice might try to chew through to gain entry but he never had any mice. Looking through the coach I couldn't find any evidence they got in so his method apparently worked. I'd also remove ALL food or any pans that might have a food odor on them. This would include a bbq.

A diesel fuel stabilizer probably wouldn't hurt. Consult your engine manual first though

Washer: run a hot and cold fill with the antifreeze in the system (not a complete fill cycle to save some antifreeze). then, a spin to get most of the water / antifreeze solution out. I do that twice.

Ice maker: My manual says pull the water line to the ice maker and no need for antifreeze. Something I have to investigate today on where the connection within the icemaker is and how to access it.
If you follow the directions for winterizing in one of the links provided from this sticky top of this forum with much more info it should help keep your coach for the winter months.

Amber turn signal light on mirror
Hey all, Anyone know where to look for fuse or wiring for the driver side amber signal light that is at the bottom of the mirror arm? The light works on the bench, havent metered the wires yet (raining) but assume there is not juice when left signal is on, where do I look.

Newmar diagrams don't spell it out....

Thanks

There is no specific fuse for that. There is a 6 pin connector at the bottom of the mirror base next to the genset. You need to check power there. Usually the light assembly is the issue. Are all of your other clearance lights and blinkers working? Those fuse are in the rear next to the chassis batteries in a fuse holder. There might be one in the front run bay under the driver window. There is wiring running through the arm. You can check at the plug or at the light. I usually get pretty good ideas from this forum, so I thought that I would share one...

purchased a 2002 newmar mountain aire 4095 this past year still learning somethings. can anyone tell me where the light switch is to turn on the ceiling rope lights. i know the one in the bedroom but not the ones in bathroom or living room.thanks

On mine, there are 110 to 12 volt transformers that feed the LEDs. The front LEDs transformer was on the passenger AV mini cabinet behind the pass seat. In the bedroom the transformer is in a cabinet next to the TV. The 12 volt lines go up to the ceiling and connect to the LED strips on the passenger side of the RV. I think the wall switch connects to the 12 volt side of the transformer and the transformer is always on (there is a power switch on it as well - which might be why the lights aren't turning on if this is OFF)

To remove the old, yellow, outdated LED (the ones you hit with the spatula), you remove the trim (long thin nails). Then pry out the LEDs from their ceiling channel and pull out the cut end from the drivers sidewall. At this point, I would measure the diameter of the old rope light and buy replacement rope light in bulk online. It's a weird size so not a lot of options what I found...When you get the new lights in hand, continue... Once that end is out, then pulling rest of rope is easy.

Now, on the passenger side be careful...because the wire side of the rope LED is fatter than the rest of rope. If you pull too hard, you might pull off the wire which is then "lost" in the ceiling. So, I would try to pull it out, but if resistance, then open up the hole diameter with a small drill or blade. Pull out the rope end with the attachment wire.

If you loose the wire (or it won't pull out enough), then you will have to cut a slot down the wall (to be hidden by the molding) You can use a reciprocating saw like Fein. You can then try to find / dig out the wire and put additional length on it (ideally with soldered connection).

You can then connect a newer same diameter 12 volt white LED strip to the old wires. Test wiring polarity because one way the LED will work, the other won't. Insulate the wires without getting the rope too fat. Insert back into the wall. Put the new rope into the channel. Cut the end to length (a little more than what is needed but at the rope LED cut lines) and push the extra into the drivers wall hole.

Put the molding back up, use a finishing gun air nailer to resecure.

The old yellow lights really dated the interior. Putting new clear, white lights "brightened" up the place.

And while I was at it, I also upgraded the fluorescent fixtures to flush mounted LED pucks.

I want to report that I've just had success replacing a failed summer loop pump for heat transfer fluid in our Oasis CH-50's Distribution Module with one of the below for only $87.85 plus tax, shipping, etc.

https://www.ussolarpumps.com/catalog...culating-pump/

N.B. You need to talk to Mike when ordering and say you need the "summer loop version" when ordering.

I did not originally talk to Mike, just ordered via the web page (a C1E 12V), and the pump that arrived had screw threads on the plastic pump housing with brass barbed adapters. This made the unit with the connectors too big to fit into the Distribution Module. When I called Mike he said "Oh, this is for a summer loop? We have a solution for that." He sent a replacement pump which I think had the plastic housing of the C1A model (based on the look of the nipples, sorry don't know what that is called) with 2 high quality hose adapters, 4 screw clamps, and 1 brass barbed adapter. Once you put the adapter hose on the pump outlet and tighten a clamp down, the other hose end is the right size for the Oasis fitting into the water heat exchanger. The other adapter hose clamps on the inlet, clamps on one end of the brass adapter, and then the other end of the adapter fits right into the heating hose feeding the pump with fluid. Easy peasey.

The hardest part was getting the existing hose off the bad pump. We ended up cutting our incoming hose just a bit past the nipple, and also cutting up the outgoing hose completely. The cuts aren't a problem because you will use the adapter hose lengths supplied by US Solar Pumps to make up for the missing pieces and lengths.

I am trying to attach a PVC fitting to the fresh water drain pipe underneath the coach. I measured the outside diameter of the drain white PVC pipe and went to Home Depot. found it is between the OD of 1 inch and ¾ inch PVC pipe. Do RVs have a different PVC pipe?

The black drain pipe in your RV is an ABS pipe. This is different than the white PVC pipe. It's important to know the difference as your RV uses ABS, not PVC. There is a reason why, namely, durability and flexibility that does not exist in PVC.

Now doubt the drain on your RV, regardless if black or grey tank is a 3 inch bayonet mount end. It's designed to connect the "stinky slinky" sewer hose with a 1/4 inch, slide in and turn motion for fast and easy hook-up and disconnect.

You'll want to use a 4 inch PVC outside the camper. 4 inch PVC pipe is pretty much the standard and 4 inch PVC connections come with threaded ends so the RV "stinky slinky" hose connection can screw into it making a tight seal.

If you are connecting directly, then you'll want to connect the black pipe (3 inch) on your camper with the 1/4 turn bayonet end, to the 4 inch smooth PVC pipe end, then connect then with a "boot".

Oh, sorry.... I just realized you are talking about the "FRESH WATER" drain....

OK, the Fresh Water Drain pipe is probably 1/2 inch PEX. You can get a shark bite connection and use that to connect to a PVC 1/2 inch WATER pipe.

Down here in hot and humid Alabama with a new puppy that needs to go out a couple times a night. Twice while doing this, the smoke detector has gone off all I can figure is that it is triggered when the hot outside air is drafting into the coach with the door open. Does this detector trigger when the air temp rises quickly? Seems like it is a little sensitive if 85 degree heat can set it off. Happened to anyone else?

No, cheap smoke detectors do NOT alarm based on heat, RoR (Rate of Rise), and certainly not in the sub-100º range.

Smoke Detectors are very sensitive to moisture (like showers), as well as dust and even cobwebs.

The usual thing to do is:

1. check the battery
2. check the date code (most detectors age out after 5 or 10 years)
3. blow it out with dry compressed air

If these maintenance items are done and it still alarms, then you're probably fighting humidity.

my best advice, be wary of buying off amazon.
They sent me a 5 year old smoke detector. Kidde stated amazon should be not selling anything that dated.

Research this yourself but there are two types of smoke detector, ionization and photoelectric. Ionization looks for any small particle and is cheaper. Photoelectruc generally have less false alarms due to humidity.

Fire marshal advice is to have both types, in this case you could try a photoelectric near door and an ionization type away from kitchen, shower and door.

I am not an expert, please do your own due diligence. Hope this helps.

Stay safe

The above is sound advice, although you may have difficulty figuring out what type they are. I never really worry too much about it.

The main brands you’ll find in the major stores will be First Alert and Kidde.

A higher end option that I’m a big fan of, ESPECIALLY IN A MOTORHOME, is a remote monitored detector like the NEST. This gives you an extra level of security by letting you monitor your RV when it’s in storage or your away for the day. Of course, you must maintain a solid internet connection for this to work. The big downside is cost.
For what it’s worth, I have been told that smoke detectors in RV’s need to be rated for use in a moving vehicle due to vibration.

Propane leak detectors beep when they need to be replaced. You have ro replace the hole unit.

Propane detectors are in the kitchen near the floor and near the sources of any propane leak, mainly the stove as everything else propane is outside vented. I don't know what would be near the passengers chair that would beep. I once lost a phone and days later heard this weird beeping...it was the phone.

But, assuming it is the propane detector, what's been mentioned is typical, powered by the RV batteries, and they beep every 15 to 25 seconds to signal end of life, and more often when they detect propane.

Most propane (LP) gas detectors have a five to seven year life expectancy. At that point they must be replaced, nothing to change out, unless you are good at soldering individual components on a circuit board. There are many different sizes so get the model number from yours and purchase a new one. You just remove two screws, clip two wires and reconnect them and screw the new one back in place. Sometimes you can't find the exact replace and you may have to make the mounting hole a little bigger.


These detectors use more power than small batteries could realistically provide over a few years. So they are powered by 12 or 120 volt power.

Hello all -
I just replaced the propane detector in our 2004 Mountain Aire 4301. I couldn't find power at the 2 wires no matter what I did. The manuals all said that there is a fuse; ours "should be" located in the bathroom at the electrical panels. There is a fuse position labeled LP Detector on the panel... BUT it isn't connected to anything so no point in puttinga fuse in an unwired socket.
I heard from another user that Newmar said that there would be an inline fuse running to the detector itself running in the line in the wall behind the detector itself, but I could not find one there, either.
Short version: there is a switch in the front control panel where A/C thermostat, tank levels, AGS system are located, and the switch only says "LP" below it. I had assumed that was an electric valve opening/closing the LP tank like on other rigs that I have had, but I was wrong.
The switch sends power to the LP detector. AH! So - now everything works with new LP detector in place and switch "On". I added a small label below the switch so that it now reads "LP Detector".

Hope this helps someone else so you don't waste time hunting for a fuse that I couldn't find, either.

Hello,
I am trying to find where the Thermostat temperature pick up are located. My coach seems to be wired wrong. Front pick up is in the rear of the coach. With the front pick up runs the rear heat.
Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Not knowing anything about what you have, it is quite possible that the thermostats were connected backwards if the thermostat was changed.
We have a 2020 Ventana 3717. I use the Oasis to keep the coach warm in winter. It seems the lowest thermostat setting I can acheive is 55 degrees. Is this correct? Thanks.

I noticed a few years ago in a Forest River TT that the Coleman thermostat lowest temperature setting was 55 degrees.

Since then, I've looked at a lot of various RVs from dealerships to RV shows and always check the thermostats.

55 degrees seems to the be the lowest setting, no matter the RV brand, or thermostat brand.

Inquiring minds wonder why?

Generally speaking, 55 degrees is the lowest setting that is recommended to keep plumbing from freezing.

This is true for stick and brick construction and would certainly be true for RV's. RV's are less well insulated.

Of course how low you can go depends on the individual unit. Measuring temperature in plumbing spaces is a good way to know.

My highly modified Kodiak Cub holds at 47 degrees in the belly plumbing spaces when thermostat is set to 65 degrees. So 55 degrees would probably lower belly temperature to 37 degrees. Any lower would allow freezing.

Do you feel lucky?

Use a portable electric heater if the plumbing has been winterized.

A couple of people asked me to post if I did the air dryer filter replacement.

I've been dreading changing the Air Dryer Filter because it's soooooo hard to access. Freightliner wanted $400.00 in labor to do the job. I started and stopped the job a couple of times today, as I just couldn't see how I could get to it. There is large (nut) hose that has to be removed and very hard to access. If I couldn't get it loose, I was done. Luckily it came loose easily.

The Bendix Air Dryer unit is mounted to the driver's frame rail, between the rear tire and tag. I ran my coach up on 6" ramps and then put blocks under the jacks. I dumped the air and drained the tanks. I extended the jacks to give me working room, but the ramps lifted the coach high enough if the jacks failed.

The Air Dryer is bolted to a bracket that is then bolted to the frame. It's also clamped at the top with a metal band. Unless the project was done over a pit or on a lift, there is no way to even reach or release the clamp at the top.

In the attached photo, you can see the metal bracket that is attached to the bottom of the air dryer. I'm pointing at the first two bolts that need to be removed, to release the air dryer assembly from the frame/bracket. The only way I was going to be able to remove the filter was to drop the air dryer assembly by moving this bracket out of the way, leaving the can still attached at the top.

Before you do any of this, there are four connections to the unit. One of the connections is a large nut (1 1/4") that takes an actual large open end to loosen, a crescent won't fit. Loosen and remove this line, unplug the quick connect sensor and then unplug two more air hoses. They're the quick connect type, where you push in on the ring and pull the hose out.

Once the hoses are removed, you need to remove two of the eight 9/16" nut/bolts that hold the filter cover on and are bolted through the support bracket. Once those are removed, you can work on the two 9/16" nut/bolts that hold the bracket to the frame. These bolts were the toughest to remove of the entire project. It was tough to access the nut on the back side, but is doable. I only removed one and loosened the other. Once one is removed, the bracket can be swung down and out of the way. You'll be glad you don't have to remove both.

Now it gets easier, there are eight 9/16" nut/bolts that hold the air dryer to the filter cover. You've already removed two. Remove five more, leaving the easiest one to access for last. Once you're down to the last one, the air dryer assembly and filter will drop out as you remove the last bolt. All eight nut/bolts had two washers each.

I took the unit out and put it on my bench. You'll most likely need a vise to hold the base as the filter is very tight. I was able to use a large pair of vise grips to spin the filter off. Once it off, there are two O-rings, one under the cartridge and one around the outer edge of the canister. The replacement unit comes with the two new O-rings and grease to lube the O-rings.

Once the new cartridge was installed in the air dryer base, I reversed the removal procedure.

I will tell you that this not a project for the faint of heart. It's a dirty project because the air dryer is in line with the rear u-joint and grease gets thrown on the air dryer. This job is not highly technical, just dirty with one hard to reach nut/bolt that holds the bracket to the frame.

I just don't understand why they make them so hard to get to! Mine is above the tag axle, the dealers service dept said they changed it as part of their PDI. And at least the date on the filter shows it was done.

My Diplomat had a spin on Wabco filter in a bay. Five minutes max and I was done. This was just idiotic. It wont need changing again for another four years, at which time I'll be 65 and either too old to do it, or driving another coach.

Wow...that does NOT sound like a lot of fun.

I was really hoping I could get purchase on the filter with a strap wrench...drain air from tanks...and just spin it off.

I admit....I have never even glanced up to see how impossible they make this job. All the Freightliner techs standing around a Chassis at Rallys say to drop the whole assembly, like you did.

It is not a project I am looking forward to.

I have not found just the louver. As shown in Redbaron's post, it's all or nothing. What a waste. I guess someone thinks the louvers never break! HA!

I am on my 3rd Newmar logo'd handle. But, this time I find I have to completely redo the mount as Newmar has decided to change the grab handle and not provide parts for the old style. So, you get to pay about $60 for their engineering update and drill NEW holes to mount the new handle, which may or may not cover the old mounting holes.
Old Broken Handle

I decided to install my new grab handle today.

This is obviously a well though out engineering update - NOT. There is nothing that interchanges. The old light socket connection is soldered in an the new one uses a twist in light socket. The screws are of a different size. It's longer and narrower. Old is molded plastic and new is metal. I suspect they decided to use the same handle as the DP's. Bottom line save money.

You have very little room to work with the wiring.

Dale,

Sorry about the troubles with your grab handle.

The new install looks good though!

It looks like the wiring (from your pic) was coming out of the top mounting piece (rather then the bottom).

Hi there! It's been a while since we've posted. Most of our problems with our new (to us) motorhome have been resolved, but a new one cropped up recently and I thought the guys at the "Newmar Owner's Forum" might be able to help us figure it out.

All of a sudden the "Pos-A-Loc" feature on the front door is catching and preventing us from closing the door. If we only open the door partially, and then close it...it's okay. But if the door opens all the way, it locks up. It has been an ordeal to get it to close once this happens. (I'm afraid John is going to break it in the process.)

John is fairly handy, and is usually able to solve these problems. He says that previously he became aware that the "Pos-A-Loc" feature did not work at all. It was not a big issue, but the door did not remain in the open position as it should have. So now, the opposite is happening. It goes into the open mode and won't come out regardless of lifting either of the door handles.

Anyone else have this problem? Anyone know what we can do to fix it? An RV repair guy who happened to be in the park recently took a look and his advice was that it would have to go back to the manufacturer. I find this hard to believe!

I would like to hear from some Newmar folks about this. Ginger

Hi Ginger,
This is a shot in the dark, but it's cheap and easy to do.

1. The male latch pin the door lock closes on should be able to move around in its' elongated slot. Grab hold of it and see if you can move the pin up/down or left/right (looking at the pin). If it is hard to move or does not move, I use a spray can of liquid wrench or similar product to loosen it up.

2. Good lubrication of the door lock is essential for continued operation. Using a spray can lubricant of your choice, spray the lubricant around the pivot points of the latch parts.

These fixes have worked for me, in the past, maybe they will work for you.

Good luck and please post your results.

On our 18 LA the baggage doors have been getting harder and harder to close and when one was really getting harder to close decided to look at it. What I found was by taking the cover off and tightening all the loose screws and lubricating the locking assembly they closed so much easier. No adjustment to the latch just tightening and lubricating. Used white grease and some T-9 for lub. Since most of the holes for the screws to hold the covers on were loose went and put some wooden tooth picks and glue in holes and let it dry over night before petting the covers back on. With this the screws were tight again. Takes a couple hours but no more NEWMAR SLAM to shut the outside baggage doors.
Newmar Man

Good work Tom. On my 21 DS, one of the first things I did was adjust all the latches so I did not have to slam them too hard. Still tight enough where no water or dust gets inside though. I checked all my latch screws and cables and all were tight. I did this when I was installing emergency release cables on all outside compartments, but I will make sure I annually check these items.

I never had side baggage doors until my current unit. I certainly can't say I'm very impressed with Newmar's design, adjustments, or latch choice. Overall I'd give them a "D" on quality baggage doors.

My first and best design enhancement was to make aluminum latch "riser/close" parts to replace the "prone-to-break" cheap plastic ones Newmar uses AND install them on all doors. No way any sag or "highway bounce" on the big doors can open them while going down the road now.
